TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate to the chamber that Senator Bolkus will be with us shortly. He had to attend a funeral in Melbourne. He will be about five minutes late.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to cabinet's decision to establish its budget salvage committee—or it might be better referred to as a save the discredited Treasurer committee. I ask: can the minister inform the Senate what exactly this committee will do? Is its establishment an admission that the strategy of staring the Senate down has failed? If in fact the government has abandoned its threatening pose as counterproductive, will the government now remove the linkage of income tax cuts to the passage of regressive tax increases?

—The committee will conduct discussions with those members of the Senate who have shown some reasonableness in being prepared to consider the measures; so we will not be talking to the opposition. The staring down issue is not worth any further consideration. I want to say something about linkage. I was hoping that Senator Hill would agree to include that in his question—that was very kind of him.

PARA.TAB: There is linkage in three forms. It has always been absolutely clear that there is a linkage between the revenue measures in this budget. It does not matter whether or not they are in the form of one bill or separate bills with a clause indicating that one tax effect is subject to the other. Whatever legislative form it takes, nothing can take away from the fact that there is a fundamental economic linkage, which is unarguable, between the capacity of a government to deliver income tax cuts, which it thinks are justified, and the passing of the revenue measures that will make it possible.

It has been clear from budget night that that linkage exists. Those opposite have to remember that in this budget we are bringing forward these tax cuts. What I am looking forward to is the circumstance on 15 November. If the legislation passes on 15 November ordinary Australian workers will get a major tax cut; a tax cut to which they are entitled. If they do not get these tax cuts because of the intransigence of the Senate, we will have a very interesting situation. I look forward to seeing those over there, who have been responsible for holding the legislation up, talking to the ordinary office workers on $500 a week about why they are missing out on a $5 a week tax cut, or talking to a nurse on $710 a week, who is not what I call rich.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are already l-a-w, law.

—Not from 15 November. The ignorance of those opposite is only being compounded by their volume. It is just another indication of quantity replacing quality in the contributions of those opposite. We have a situation where ordinary Australian workers, like nurses on $700 a week, will lose $14 every week in the tax cuts until they are passed. A bus driver will miss out on $9 a week every fortnight the Senate delays the passage of these bills.

PARA.TAB: I look forward to those opposite going out to those workplaces, because we will be going out there explaining to people why they are not getting those increases. People talk about these cuts somehow being a pay-off to the wealthy, but we are talking about tax cuts that assist ordinary Australian workers to get the sort of tax cut to which they are entitled. Millions of Australian workers on average earnings will miss out on the extra dollars they are entitled to in their pay packet if the Senate continues with the irresponsible and damaging political game playing which those opposite have been undertaking until now. PARA.TAB: Following that invitation I have been in consultation with the parties involved in the dispute and I have been following the progress of the discussions in the commission. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Last year the discredited present Treasurer promised tax cuts with no strings attached when he told the parliament, `The point is, the tax cuts can be funded without any new taxes'. Why then did Senator McMullan tell the Senate yesterday that there is and always has been a linkage between the revenue increases and the tax cuts? Is this not just another example of Labor's utter lack of moral scruple and its willingness to say or do anything to stay in power?

I will deal specifically with the question of what this budget proposes about tax cuts.
—Answer the question.
—That is what the question is. This budget is proposing two things that are relevant to this point. One is that we are bringing forward the tax cuts—
—Half of them.
—All that were going to apply this year. We are bringing forward the tax cuts and that has revenue implications. It is important that we balance those.
—You are bringing forward one-third and totally abandoning two-thirds.

—We are bringing forward tax cuts for those workers to whom I referred before. We are bringing forward tax cuts for those office workers, nurses, bus drivers and other ordinary workers to whom those tax cuts are targeted, who deserve them and to whom we wish to give them. Therefore, we have to consistently deal with revenue measures that would compensate for that necessary bringing forward.

PARA.TAB: That bringing forward does one other very important thing that people do not like to recognise. The other important thing about bringing forward the tax cuts, and why we want to do it, is that they are also a very important economic stimulus. Bringing forward the tax cuts will provide an extra $300 million of expenditure. It will pump $300 million into the Australian economy before Christmas, if they are passed in time for them to take effect on 15 November. That extra expenditure starts to generate the retail sales which are good not only for the individuals who have the capacity to make it but also for the retail sector and for Australia's employment. It is an important element of economic stimulus, so we wish to be able to deliver the cuts.

We also have in this budget over four years a deficit reduction strategy, which is a very important strategy. It is not an easy balance to strike to increase the deficit in the first year to generate the necessary economic stimulus and similarly over a four-year period to deliver a deficit reduction strategy which will get the deficit down to 1.1 or 1.2 per cent—very close to one per cent—of GDP. It is an outstanding achievement internationally and in the terms of Australia's macro-economic history. There are few occasions on which that has been achieved to that extent.

We are trying to strike a delicate balance. It may be too complex for Senator Alston, but the tax increases are necessary to fund that bring forward and to deal with the necessary deficit reduction strategy to get the deficit down to one per cent of GDP.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs. What is the current situation regarding the establishment of a new government in Cambodia? What steps are being taken to withdraw the UN forces from that country?

—Friday, 24 September, was an important day for people in Cambodia. On that day they promulgated the new Cambodian national constitution, which was a vital step forward for the independence of that country. Today is equally a very important day for Cambodia. The significance of today is that for the first time the newly constituted national assembly is meeting in Phnom Penh.

PARA.TAB: On behalf of the Australian government—and I believe I speak for the Senate in this as well—I extend my warmest congratulations to the national assembly of Cambodia in its first meeting in Phnom Penh today. I congratulate not only the members of that assembly, but all those who have helped achieve this outstanding outcome, including many important Australians.

This previously shattered nation has been rendered whole now, with its own democratically elected national assembly assuming responsibilities for ongoing peace and stability in that country. It means that the United Nations brokered peace process in Cambodia has achieved its primary objective of returning to the Cambodian people the responsibility for their own destiny. We acknowledge and salute this outstanding achievement of the United Nations peacekeeping force.

UNTAC's mandate formally ended on 24 September, the day on which the new constitution was promulgated. Under the constitution, Cambodia has become a constitutional monarchy, under which the monarch reigns but does not govern. Prince Ranariddh and Mr Hun Sen were appointed co-prime ministers. On the same day, Prince Sihanouk took office as King of Cambodia. The progressive withdrawal of UNTAC personnel is proceeding, including that of the Australian Defence Force contingent, and it is to be completed by 15 November this year.

Australia shares the sense of celebration and satisfaction surrounding these developments in Cambodia. It has extended warm congratulations to King Sihanouk and the two prime ministers, Prince Ranariddh and Mr Hun Sen. It should be remembered that Australia has made a significant contribution to the peacekeeping process, and the government commends all those Australians involved. Particular mention must be made of Lieutenant-General Sanderson, who has served as military commander of UNTAC with great distinction. I think particular mention should be made of foreign minister Gareth Evans for his distinguished service in helping bring about this outcome.

The future of Cambodia is now in the hands of the Cambodians, but it is the nature of the peace accord that the settlement process does not end with the completion of UNTAC's mandate; rather, it is a continuing international process by which the signatories are committed in a variety of ways to assisting Cambodia. These include the reconstruction of Cambodia through their involvement in the International Committee of Reconstruction in Cambodia; assistance on human rights questions through the Special Representative Commission on Human Rights; and assistance through whatever individual countries may do bilaterally.

Australia is committed to supporting the new government. Our aid program is generous and is directed towards humanitarian and development needs, including a contribution to the removal of mines from that country. The people of Australia wish the people of Cambodia peace and prosperity as Cambodians begin the task of transforming and reconstructing this brutalised nation. We look forward to Cambodia's full and fruitful partnership with Australia and with other countries of the Asia-Pacific region.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to the black spot road construction program which received funding of $180 million in last year's budget. Is the minister aware that this program is credited with a substantial and cost effective reduction of road deaths by eliminating dangerous road conditions? Why is there no provision for it in this budget, which is almost devoid of public infrastructure investment? If further funding is dependent on yet another review, why was this not done early enough to ensure that there was no break in the program which is providing both a substantial reduction in road accidents and badly needed employment?

—I am surprised by the assertion in the second part of Senator Spindler's question that this budget does not provide any significant capital investment for infrastructure. In this budget the federal government has allocated $1.2 billion for roads. As well a further $350 million has been allocated to local authorities for transport infrastructure. This year has also seen the expenditure of $300 million on rail infrastructure, that is, the bulk of the spending of the $450 million—
—A drop in the bucket!

—It might be a drop in the bucket for the Australian Democrats but we on this side of the House actually have to make the sums work. I respectfully point out to Senator Spindler that the $450 million we have put into rail in One Nation, $300 million of which will be spent this year, is one of the biggest single injections into new capital works on railways in living memory.

PARA.TAB: The original black spots program was announced on 5 December 1989. It was a comprehensive road safety package which was aimed at reducing the national road toll. It had a planned three year life. It was always intended that the program would expire at the end of June this year. Between 1990 and 1993 an amount of $110 million was allocated to eliminate a range of hazardous accident black spots. Funding to the states and territories was conditional on their accepting a 10 point package of enhanced road safety measures—a reduction in the alcohol limits being one of the more prominent measures. This original allocation was further boosted by an additional $110 million worth of One Nation funds and a further allocation of $60 million in the 1992-93 budget.

This total of more than $260 million was fully disbursed to the states and territories before the planned completion of the program in June this year. The package has been fully implemented everywhere, except Western Australia and the Northern Territory, where a few aspects await final implementation. Over 3,000 identified black spots have been eliminated during the three year life of the program, which is now being analysed by the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics. The report on this analysis will be completed later this year. I will make sure that Senator Spindler and indeed all senators get a copy of it.

The purpose of the black spots program was twofold: firstly, the program was offered as an incentive for the states to agree to national standards on 10 important road safety issues; secondly, the program was designed to demonstrate to state and local authorities the value in directly addressing known accident black spots within their funding programs. The vast majority of these black spots are on local roads or state arterial roads.

With the new separation of road funding responsibilities arising out of the July 1991 meeting of heads of government, the Commonwealth's responsibility will be restricted to the National Highway and, as Senator Spindler knows, significant additional federal funds are to be distributed as untied grants. In conclusion, I do find it difficult to have sympathy for those states that demand additional road funding when they fail to spend the untied funds they currently receive on roads.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services. From media comments I am aware that the Canberra based National Museum of Australia launched recently in Albury-Wodonga a major travelling exhibition entitled A changing people—A changing land. What is the purpose of this exhibition; and is this an indication of the future direction the museum will take?

—It is very significant that the first exhibition launched by the National Museum, since it received its budget funding for the initial development work on its site, is a travelling exhibition which has been launched in Albury-Wodonga. It is a travelling exhibition essentially featuring the Murray-Darling Basin, and it will be travelling that area for the next 18 months. It is entitled A changing people—A changing land and is the first major travelling exhibition. It will visit a number of centres in the Murray-Darling region including, I am advised, Bendigo, Goolwa, Mildura, and will travel as far north as Toowoomba, Dubbo and Canberra. It is an important part of telling the Australian story. It is one of the things that the National Museum has the potential to do very well, if it develops as we hope it will.

PARA.TAB: The organisation of this exhibition, its development and now its travelling arrangements reflect the truly national outlook which the museum has and which we want to emphasise in its development. If it is to be a national museum, it has to be accessible to Australians wherever they are; it has to be relevant to Australians wherever they live. Each community to which the exhibition will go has contributed to the exhibition, and the displays they create with the museum about their local history and the changes in their landscapes will remain in the local community as a permanent, continuing educational resource for those communities.

It is easy to say things about increasing access to collecting institutions and cultural institutions in general, but it is more important than merely a question of who comes through the door. It is very important to be thrusting out beyond the level of the institution, particularly in a country with our geography and distribution of population.

The government's goal with regard to the National Museum of Australia as it has developed is to have 80 per cent of its users outside Canberra by the year 2001. I think that is an important aspect of the national emphasis of the National Museum of Australia. We very much wish it to be a museum to which individual Australians can easily make contact and with which they can easily communicate from time to time.
This philosophy is also carried through in two other related areas of initiative that the government has developed in the area of the arts.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think they are very important, particularly to the National Party's constituents—and to some of Senator MacGibbon's constituents because this is very important in Queensland. The Queensland government has been very cooperative in this, as have the other state governments, in particular with regard to the distributed national collection and the new proposal for a visual arts project building on the successful touring of the performing arts.

PARA.TAB: Those things are part of a consistent philosophy of saying that people around Australia, wherever they live, contribute their taxes to fund these institutions and arts activities. They are entitled to have the greatest access we can provide to those institutions and to the collections that they hold and the skills developed by the individuals whom they help fund. We are seeking to give them that access. The important exhibition launched in Albury-Wodonga by the National Museum is an important step in implementing that philosophy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. What study has the government done on the effect of its fuel excise increases on rural and regional Australia? Does the minister not understand that the increases in transport costs will disproportionately hurt rural and regional Australia in prices for fuel, food, housing and travel; and why did the government deliberately fashion a budget which hurts most those who can least afford it?

—There has been a lot of consideration over the years in Australia about fuel taxes and about the relative impact of fuel taxes, about the fact that Australia has such a relatively low level of fuel tax compared with other countries. I acknowledge that there are regional, economic and environmental consequences and historical reasons for that very low level. Nevertheless, we have to acknowledge that by international standards it is extremely low.

PARA.TAB: There is no need for new studies every time people propose to change such taxes. This has been well studied in Australia over the years. All tax increases have an impact on people who have to pay them. By definition, none of them is popular and it is always easy for oppositions to vote against them. In the past, oppositions have been too principled to fall for that, but I suppose no-one should expect this opposition to have that sort of shortcoming.

Everybody is aware of the regional, rural and distributional impacts of tax changes—not just fuel tax changes but any tax changes. Therefore, it is very important that, if we are proceeding with such changes, we look at compensating mechanisms. It is very important that the Senate proceeds to deal with the range of tax measures so that the income tax cuts will flow to people and assist them to meet the increased costs. It would be a great travesty if people here purporting to be concerned about the impact on individual citizens were to act in a way that denied them the tax cuts to which they are entitled.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister for Trade arises from reports overnight about the outcome of the meeting between Sir Leon Brittan and the United States chief trade negotiator, Mickey Kantor. Can the minister inform the Senate how he now views the prospects for a successful conclusion of the Uruguay Round this year?

—I think the prospects can be summarised as being brighter than they were previous to this meeting. Maybe the opposition does not share this view and maybe it is into gloom-mongering but I am sure that anyone with any realistic appreciation of the events would come to the same conclusion.

PARA.TAB: Out of the discussions overnight—yesterday our time—there is now I think a real recognition by the Europeans and particularly in the United States that 15 December this year is a genuine deadline; that the Uruguay Round is of international significance and that it must be completed; that the talks that have been going on between the United States and the European Commission should be multilateralised—that is to say, other countries, as contracting parties to the GATT, should now be included. The United States has made it very clear to the Europeans that the Blair House accord, a modification of the Dunkel draft final act, is the rock bottom position for them—that they will not compromise further.

Australia has made it clear that we support that. Australia, as chairman of the Cairns Group of fair trading agricultural countries, has underlined the significance of no compromises on the draft final act. It is pleasing to see that these points have been registered strongly now with the Europeans in the talks that occurred overnight—yesterday in calender time.

We now believe that, as I have emphasised in my direct discussions with Sir Leon Brittan and Mickey Kantor, we should build a big market access package. We think that the Blair House accord deals with only half the problem; it reduces the level of subsidy. The question of access to markets is the other half of the problem and that must be the issue that is now focused on as well.

There are only 11 weeks left before 15 December and the round concluding. Therefore, it is significant to note that as well yesterday the IMF, the World Bank and the GATT itself—through their leading spokespeople, Mr Michel Camdessus, Lewis Preston and Peter Sutherland—issued a joint statement calling for the conclusion of the Uruguay Round. They called on nations to recognise that there is so much at stake that `political hesitations and vested interests must now be put aside'.

They emphasise that it is of enormous significance that these Bretton Woods organisations have come out so clearly and made their points so forcefully. This follows a joint report by the World Bank and the OECD which estimates that the value of a good outcome for the Uruguay Round—properly implemented up to the end of this century—in agricultural and industrial products alone will be worth an income boost of $327 billion to global economic activity by the year 2002. That is $16 billion more than a previous estimate. Within that figure Australia can calculate that the boost in extra income to us is about $2.5 billion.

Therefore, I share the sense of optimism now being generated about the round's conclusions. The important issue is that farmers in France should not be able to jack up this round and hold the world to ransom. They constitute about four per cent of the GDP of France. For France not to recognise that its economic fortunes are best served by a good outcome for the round and to cave in to a small group of vested interests and jack up this round would be the wrong outcome. It is in the interests of France and the world that we now conclude it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the cabinet decision to establish a budget salvage committee to assist the Treasurer to get his budget through the Senate. Does the formation of this committee indicate that the government is now prepared to give ground on wine tax increases which will seriously damage this rapidly growing industry?
—It certainly does not. The situation with the wine tax is quite clear. We regard it as a very equitable measure. It is a measure that starts to—
—For beer drinking Labor voters.
—I am happy to say that a few wine drinkers vote Labor too. As Ross Gittins said in—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to say that at the last election more people who drank anything—including metho—voted for us rather than for those opposite. After the budget measures, the total tax per litre of actual alcohol will be about $49 for spirits, $18 for full strength beer and $3 for cask wine. What we are talking about is not a change that massively disadvantages the wine industry.

PARA.TAB: Of course, every industry in Australia would far prefer not to be taxed and it is true that all of them could be more successful if they were not taxed. There is no doubt about that. If we said to the beer industry, `We are no longer going to tax you', there would be a big surge in that industry and we could create a lot more jobs—more than we can by taking tax off the wine industry, if it is jobs those opposite are concerned about.

We have a tax measure that disproportionately raises revenue from upper income groups and, to the extent that it has any industry effect, it can only be by substitution, so that there will be more people drinking, whatever the alternative is that they choose to drink instead of wine. We have a situation where we have a very important revenue measure, essentially equitable—

TALK.START.PARA: —You should have a coherent industry policy.

—Senator Kernot is not talking about coherent industry policy. She is not taking any account of the substitution effect on the alternative industries, like the beer industry, which employs a lot more people. If people stop drinking wine it will be because of a substitution effect, not because of a reduction. There is no evidence that people drink less. The evidence is of a substitution effect—people drink different things. One has to appreciate the fundamental level of economics—that that will generate the same or more jobs in other industries. PARA.TAB: The worst thing this Senate can do for the wine industry is what it has done so far, which is generate that massive amount of uncertainty which is causing great problems for the industry. If one talks to the industry about what its biggest problem is today, one finds it is uncertainty. If this wine tax is not carried, we will not have delivered certainty to that industry, we will have delivered continuing uncertainty because we will not have exhausted the government's interest in pursuing the question of equitable revenue in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Removing this tax immediately will also deliver certainty to the industry. The Minister conveniently overlooks the fact that in the last 10 years the government has put the tax up from zero per cent to 10 per cent to 20 per cent to 31 per cent now. Why does the government persist with the threat to withhold tax cuts that Australians were promised unless the increased wine tax and other measures are agreed to when the reality is that there is no certainty that any of these measures, especially the increased wine tax, will get through the Senate?

—I have answered this question several times. The linkage issue is quite clear and will continue. Senator Tierney is quite wrong to say that defeating the wine tax will deliver certainty to the industry; it will not. The industry knows it. If Senator Tierney asks it, it will tell him.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. By way of preamble, I point out that the national forest policy agreed to by the Commonwealth and all the states, with the exception of Tasmania, undertakes to `avoid activities which may significantly affect those areas of old-growth forest or wilderness that are likely to have high conservation value'. Minister Kelly has sent an indicative list of areas which required interim protection until the reserve system was established to each state. The list included the Nalbaugh State Forest in New South Wales. Given that the minister considers the Nalbaugh State Forest to be of high conservation value, what is she doing to prevent its destruction by the New South Wales Forestry Commission, in complete defiance of the agreed national forest policy? Secondly, does the government put cooperation with recalcitrant state governments ahead of implementation of its own policy?

—On 22 December 1992 Minister Kelly wrote to the relevant New South Wales ministers, outlining action necessary to meet the conservation initiatives of the national forest policy statement. She specifically noted the commitment to avoid activities in areas likely to have a high conservation value, pending assessment of these areas for determination against agreed reserve selection criteria and advised that funding assistance for assessments of old-growth forests and wilderness was available from the Commonwealth. Attached to her letter was a list of areas, including the Nalbaugh State Forest, that warranted consideration by the New South Wales government in light of the NFPS conservation policies.

PARA.TAB: On 31 May 1993 Mrs Kelly wrote to the New South Wales Minister for Land and Water Conservation seeking support for old-growth studies in New South Wales as a matter of priority. To date, no reply has been received. She shares the community's concern that the NFPS commitments are honoured by signatory governments. However, we must emphasise that the national forest policy is a joint Commonwealth-state policy statement and its implementation depends on the willingness of state governments who have signed the policy to give effect of its intentions. To this end, Mrs Kelly has requested information from the New South Wales Minister for the Environment on how current forest management practices applying to the Nalbaugh and Dewar areas serve to protect the high conservation values that have been identified in the region. She has also written to the Commonwealth Minister for Resources, given his responsibilities for export approvals, regarding the Nalbaugh special prescription area and the conservation initiatives of the NFPS.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Trade. I am glad he also represents the Minister for Foreign Affairs. In light of Australia's decision to lift sanctions against South Africa, I ask: firstly, what is the outlook for Australia's uranium industry now that uranium rich South Africa is free to compete against us in world markets; and, secondly, when will the federal government abandon its notorious three mine uranium policy in Australia and give our uranium industry an even break?

—This is an odd question because, clearly, part of it does not touch the trade portfolio. Nonetheless, one can never expect Senator Tambling to get anything perfectly right. I do not have to hand an assessment of what the outlook is for the export of uranium from Australia, in view of the lifting of trade sanctions to South Africa. It is true that there are uranium stocks in South Africa, to the best of my knowledge, and, if they become available to the world market, as is likely, then the price of uranium is likely to fall and the prospects for all uranium producing countries are likely to be bleaker in an already overhung market.

PARA.TAB: But it is also true that South Africa is a competitive producer of many mineral commodities. On some of those commodities South Africa competes with Australia. The bans on South Africa were never imposed because of competition or fear of competition in respect of any mineral commodity or any other good or service. The ban on South Africa was imposed because that country formerly had an entrenched policy of apartheid in its constitution. We took part, with other countries in the world, in imposing a ban because that policy is racist and it is a fundamental denial of human rights. It is due to the changes in South Africa that we heeded the call of Nelson Mandela at the United Nations General Assembly just last week and removed our ban.

On the fact that this measure has other trade implications, so be it; we will meet fair competition fairly. We are a highly productive country that supplies our goods and services and our mineral commodities efficiently. We supply a quality product on time and to price, and that reputation will stand us in good stead when we deal with any emerging competition from South Africa or anywhere else in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his logic free answer. In light of the fact that he talked about the ban on apartheid, I ask: what about the ban on Australian uranium today? Why does the federal Labor government insist on handing over export dollars to the rest of the world? Is not our uranium, or our uranium industry, good enough?
—I suppose I should thank the honourable senator for his insult laden question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday in question time Senator Bell asked me a question concerning recent university research which suggested that 82 per cent of Aboriginal and Torres Strait islanders would fail at least one unit of their degree course and that women were five times less likely than men to repay their HECS debt by the age of 30. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided me with a response which I now seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: Higher Education Contribution Scheme (HECS) and its Impact on Access and Equity in Higher Education
Although women may repay more slowly, the level of their debt is maintained in real terms through cost of living adjustments—no real rate of interest is charged.

The slower repayment rate indicates that HECS is meeting its objective of being an income-contingent scheme, allowing graduates to move in and out of the work force, for example for child rearing purposes.

While repayment rates for males and females differ, the study showed that most of the total debt (96% for men and 77% for women) will be repaid to the government. The Wran committee, which recommended the introduction of HECS, estimated that some 30% of the debt would not be repaid.
The HECS scheme is recognised as a most equitable arrangement for funding higher education and a number of countries are examining the scheme for possible introduction.

It should be noted that the objective of the measure of introducing 1.5 HECS under clearly defined circumstances was not primarily to achieve savings, but to establish the principle that students who have consumed their `fair share' of higher education at maximum government subsidy should be required to pay more. It needs to be recognised that a student who fails to complete his or her course and who is permitted to stay at the university, excludes another school leaver or young person from attending.
It is important to note that:

The measure is based on equivalent full-time student load and is not related to a `time' concept as such—students will, therefore, be able to reduce their workload if necessary without incurring the higher HECS charge;
The additional one half of one standard student load is already provided as a period of grace to students who may be struggling to complete;

In the case of students whose academic progress might be expected to be slower than is customary, higher education institutions have been encouraged to advise such students to pace themselves which is possible as they need to undertake no more than 75% of a full year's load without prejudicing their entitlement to Austudy or Abstudy.

Under existing procedures, students who are forced to withdraw for reasons beyond their control after the census date, may apply to the secretary of DEET for remission of their debt for that semester. The draft guidelines on the changes to HECS propose that units remitted will not be counted against the student's accumulated student load.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement on behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) relating to his recent visit to the United States, the United Kingdom, Ireland, France and Monaco, to incorporate the statement in Hansard and to move to take note of the statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: VISIT BY THE PRIME MINISTER TO THE UNITED STATES, THE UNITED KINGDOM, IRELAND, FRANCE AND MONACO
Mr President
I wish to inform the Senate of the outcome of the Prime Minister's visit to the United States, the United Kingdom, Ireland, France and Monaco between 11 and 24 September.

During the visit, the Prime Minister dealt with a number of issues which will have a profound bearing on Australia's trading interests and future prosperity, on our national identity, and on how we and others see our place in the world.
These are all big questions, and it is important that we get them right.
At a time of great fluidity in international affairs, we now face fundamental questions about the structure of the world trading system.
The opportunity to secure a successful conclusion of the Uruguay Round is now close at hand, but the outcome is far from assured.
The APEC forum, which Australia has done so much to bring forward, is now poised to develop into a valuable framework for promoting trade and investment in the Asia-Pacific region.
The United States Congress will soon decide whether or not to approve the North American Free Trade Agreement with far-reaching repercussions either way on the US trade policy stance.

At this pivotal moment in the international trading environment, it is important that Australians are fully aware of the impact that decisions about future trade structures will have on our interests.
Mr President
At stake is nothing less than the future prosperity of our country.
At stake is our capacity to provide employment for the next generation of Australians.
More than ever before, Australia is on its own internationally, fending for itself in a competitive and challenging international environment.
But we are seen internationally as a modern society with many assets to help us make our way successfully in the world.

Our recent achievements in fostering a tolerant and diverse multicultural society and in executing a series of major reforms of the Australian economy highlight our capacity to change, and to play an increasing role in regional and international affairs.
These subjects were the main thrust of the Prime Minister's discussions in each of the capitals I visited.
Mr President
The Prime Minister visited Washington at a time Australia's most pressing interests coincide with much that is prominent on the American agenda.
The future of the Uruguay Round, the development of APEC and the creation of NAFTA are all matters to which President Clinton, his Administration and the Congress are giving high priority.
It was a very useful time to be able to put Australia's view, and to represent our interests on these issues.

Given the enormous stakes involved, it was important to be able to discuss with the US Administration and Congress what sort of policy and institutional framework will best maintain and strengthen the highly valuable economic linkages which now operate between East Asia, Oceania and North America.

So strong have these linkages between North America and the Western Pacific become over the last decade that today there is a higher degree of trade integration among the 15 members of APEC than there is among the members of the European Community, or among the three North American economies, or among the East Asian economies considered separately.

And while the United States market remains vitally important for most East Asian economies, the Prime Minister found a growing awareness in the Administration and in Congress that East Asia has also become an increasingly important market for US exports.
Indeed, less than a decade ago more than one third of Western Pacific exports went to the United States.
Today the proportion is less than one quarter.
Over the same period the proportion of US exports which go to the Western Pacific has risen to well over one quarter, on a par with those to the NAFTA partners and well ahead of exports to the EC.
Since the mid eighties the trend rate of growth of US exports to the Western Pacific has been three times the rate of growth of Western Pacific exports to the United States.

This rapid trade growth in the region and the prosperity it produces would be gravely threatened, in the Prime Minister's view, if in coming decades North America and the Western Pacific went separate ways in trade and strategic alignments.
The Prime Minister is glad to be able to report that the Clinton Administration is as convinced of the importance of the East Asia region as we ourselves have become.

The Prime Minister had very productive discussions in Washington with President Clinton, with Secretary of State Christopher, Defense Secretary Aspin, US Trade Representative Kantor, Treasury Secretary Bentsen, Director of Central Intelligence Woolsey and with senior Congressional leaders including Senate Majority Leader Mitchell, Senate Minority Leader Dole and House President Foley.
The Prime Minister's meeting with President Clinton was exceptionally useful.
The Prime Minister was impressed by the vigour, imagination and resolve with which he is going about the task of rebuilding American competitiveness and American society.
We affirmed in our meeting the continuing vitality and relevance of Australia's bilateral relationship with the United States.

Despite the great changes in the world brought about by the end of the Cold War, fundamental Australian interests continue to be engaged in our relationship with the United States—in our defence alliance, in the mutually beneficial processes of policy consultation we enjoy on a wide range of issues, and in our strong commercial ties.
Despite our bilateral access problems, which the Prime Minister discussed with Ambassador Kantor and congressional leaders, the US market remains Australia's second biggest.
And the United States is the largest source of foreign investment in Australia and the most important destination for Australian investment abroad.
Mr President
The Prime Minister's meeting with the President produced three important results.
First, they agreed to work closely together for a successful outcome of the informal APEC leaders' meeting in Seattle in November.

This historic meeting, involving leaders of the key Asia-Pacific economies—the fastest growing area of the world—will help define an Asia-Pacific economic community and give political authority and weight to APEC.
The President noted Australia's vital contribution to the development of APEC.

The Prime Minister was impressed by the President's commitment to the Asia-Pacific economic community, and by the unanimity with which he, his Cabinet and the Congressional leadership in both Houses and both parties expressed their conviction that the United States should assign a higher priority to its trading relations with the Western Pacific.

Secondly, they agreed that it was very important to world growth and jobs to achieve a successful and balanced outcome to the Uruguay Round by the 15 December deadline for Congress's "fast track" approval, and that any move by the European
Community to re-open the Blair House accord on agriculture would seriously jeopardise the whole Round.
The United States has pressed hard in favour of freer trade during seven long years of the GATT negotiations.
It has been a policy stance of great value to Australia.

But the Prime Minister was convinced by his discussions in Washington that 15 December is a real deadline for Congress, and that, if we cannot achieve an acceptable package by then, Congress as well as the Administration will turn their attention away from global solutions to trade problems and towards more regional approaches.

Thirdly, the President and Ambassador Kantor recognised Australia's concern about the damage that EEP subsidies cause our grain exports, and said they would make every effort to minimise the effect on Australia's interests.
They noted the Administration's decision to stay out of the Indonesian market as a bona fide of their sincerity in this regard.

They explained that the EEP was aimed at counteracting European subsidies, and that the only fully effective way to reduce the impact on Australia's grain exports was to conclude the Uruguay Round as soon as possible.
Mr President
In New York, the Prime Minister addressed a meeting of the Asia Society and had a meeting with the Secretary-General of the United Nations, Mr Boutros Boutros-Ghali.
The Prime Minister told the Secretary-General that Australia welcomed the new possibilities for the work of the United Nations which have arisen with the disappearance of Cold War constraints.
The Prime Minister said that, as a foundation member of the United Nations, Australia is fully committed to the ideals of the Charter and wants to see those ideals prosper.
The Prime Minister noted that Australia was committed to peace keeping, with around 600 Australians serving in Cambodia, Somalia and in other operations around the globe.
We were also a substantial financial contributor to the United Nations, paying in full and on time.
The Prime Minister told the Secretary-General that Australia would continue to contribute resources and ideas to the Organisation.
The most recent example of this contribution is Senator Evans's document "Cooperating for Peace", examining peacekeeping and conflict resolution, which is being launched in New York this week.

The Prime Minister also made it clear to the Secretary-General, however, that the United Nations Organisation itself had to make sure it was operating as efficiently and effectively as it could—especially in its administration and in its peacekeeping operations—if it was to maintain the international support needed to fulfil its great potential.
Mr President

The Prime Minister's visit to the United Kingdom, the first by an Australian Prime Minister since 1987, provided an opportunity to help reinforce and reshape this old and still very valuable relationship.
The Prime Minister had a long and productive meeting in London with Prime Minister Major.
World trade issues were again the main theme of the Prime Minister's discussions.

The Prime Minister told Prime Minister Major how much Australia appreciated the very constructive and positive role Britain has played within the EC, and more widely, in pushing the cause of freer world markets and the multinational trading system.
They both underlined the importance of a successful and balanced outcome to the Uruguay Round for jobs and growth.
They agreed that 15 December is a real deadline for the Round.
They also discussed the strong and growing economic ties between Britain and Australia.
Britain is Australia's fourth largest trading partner, and our eighth largest export market.
It is the second largest source of foreign investment in Australia.
In turn, we are the fourth largest foreign investor in the UK, ranking above Japan.
Prime Minister Major and the Prime Minister agreed that there was much to build on and to develop in this area.
They noted that an important Australia-UK trade and investment conference, to be held in Melbourne in January next year, will help to maintain the impetus for growth in our commercial relationship.
Mr President
The Prime Minister also spoke to Prime Minister Major about Australia's constitutional arrangements.

The Prime Minister said publicly in London that it is not because our affections for Britain are reduced or the friendship between us frailer, or our respect and admiration for the institutions Britain has bequeathed us in any way diminished, that Australia is considering the option of becoming a republic.
And the Prime Minister also said that our friendship for Britain would be all the stronger for our becoming a republic, as any friendship is stronger for being more mature.

Mr Major—Prime Minister of a Conservative British Government—and Mr Hurd, his Foreign Secretary who was on a parallel visit to Australia, both made publicly and privately clear that the matter of Australia's constitutional arrangements is one for the Government, people and Parliament of Australia and the Queen of Australia.
They both assert, quite correctly, that the modern, mature relationship between Britain and Australia will remain quite unaffected by our moves to become a republic.
Mr President
The Prime Minister was received by Her Majesty the Queen at Balmoral Castle on 18 September.
In accordance with longstanding convention, the discussion between them must remain confidential.

But the Prime Minister is able to say he explained to Her Majesty that, notwithstanding the deep respect and warm affection felt towards her by the Australian people, there was a growing feeling in Australia that constitutional changes should be made to allow the appointment of an Australian Head of State.
The Prime Minister outlined to Her Majesty the various steps that would be involved in such a process, including the need for a referendum to approve constitutional amendments.

The Prime Minister said the Australian Government's view was that, if approved by the Australian people at a referendum, it would be appropriate for Australia to become a republic by the centenary of Federation in 2001.

The Prime Minister told Her Majesty that, in such a situation, Australia would remain a member of the Commonwealth of Nations, and that the Australian people would warmly welcome visits to Australia by Her Majesty as Head of the Commonwealth and as the Queen of the United Kingdom.
Her Majesty authorised the Prime Minister to say that she would, of course, act on the advice of her Australian Ministers, as she always has, and on any decision made by the Australian people.
Mr President
The issues involved in the creation of a Federal Republic of Australia are complex.
They require thoughtful and informed debate.

But as a result of the Prime Minister's discussions in Britain it is clear that, whatever the outcome of the debate in Australia, whatever the form of constitutional arrangements on which the Australian people finally decide, both Her Majesty and the British Government regard these arrangements, properly, as entirely matters to be decided by the Australian people themselves.

And it is also clear that the results of any constitutional changes are not seen as a threat—and will not threaten—the warmth of the relationship between Australia and Britain, or the personal respect and affection in which Her Majesty is held.

It is the Government's firm intention, Mr President, to ensure that, throughout the period that Australians are debating new constitutional arrangements, our existing links with the monarchy are maintained and exercised with dignity and respect.

In that regard, the Prime Minister is pleased to announce that he discussed with Her Majesty an invitation he has extended to the Prince of Wales to visit Australia early in 1994 following proposals by several State Governments.
The invitation has been accepted.
His Royal Highness will arrive in Sydney on 25 January, and visit, in addition to New South Wales, Tasmania, Western Australia and Queensland.
Mr President
The Prime Minister's visit to Ireland enabled him to mark the very important contribution which Ireland has made to the cultural, social and political development of this country.
The people-to-people links between us are still strong and vigorous.
In Dublin the Prime Minister had the honour of addressing the Dail, and he had extensive discussions with the Taoiseach, Mr Reynolds, and leaders of the other Irish political parties.
The Prime Minister's discussions focused again on the outcome for the Uruguay Round, on which Ireland has been one of the European countries most resistant to change in the area of agriculture.

The Prime Minister put the view forcefully to Irish political leaders, and to business people at a dinner hosted by the Irish-Australian Business Association, that Ireland, with its growing industrial exports, will be best served by ensuring that we get an acceptable outcome to the Uruguay Round.
That in turn depended, the Prime Minister said, on the integrity of the Blair House accord on agriculture being fully maintained.
The Prime Minister also made the point that, although our trade is growing, the warmth of people-to-people relations between Australia and Ireland is not matched by our commercial links.
The Prime Minister said he hoped that companies in each country would increasingly use the other as a base to develop links into Asia and Europe respectively.
The warmth displayed by the Irish people towards the Prime Minister as head of the Government of Australia was quite profound.
In all parts of the country the Prime Minister visited, there was a spontaneous expression of warm welcome and good wishes towards Australia and the Australian people.
It is quite a phenomenon that the cultural and emotional links between Australia and this small country in Europe exists as strongly as they do.
It is something Australians should value and continue to nurture.
Mr President

On the Prime Minister's way from Ireland to Monaco for the Sydney Olympic bid, he stopped for several hours in France and visited Villers-Bretonneux, the site of the memorial to the 46,000 Australians—18,000 without a known grave—who died on the Western Front during the First World War.

Like all who have visited the military graveyards of France, the Prime Minister was reminded of the courage and devotion of those young Australians who fought and died in that terrible war and the huge loss this nation suffered on the French battlefields.
The Prime Minister was also reminded that the tragedy of which they were victims arose, in large part, from the selfish and narrow nationalism which has so often scarred this century.

We have the opportunity, as the century ends, to do things better, to create broader, more inclusive economic structures which will generate new growth and new jobs around the globe by maximising trading opportunities for all countries.

If the international community fails in its efforts to resolve the Uruguay Round by mid-December, there are other options available but, as all those the Prime Minister spoke to on his visit agreed, they are not such good options.
Mr President
The International Olympic Committee's decision to award the Olympic Games for the year 2000 to Sydney was a wonderful outcome for this country.
The Olympics are bound to be a marvellous moment in the life of the city and the nation: a celebration of international youth and sport in a young country with extraordinary sporting traditions.
All of Australia's attractions will be on show to billions of people around the world as we approach the centenary of the Commonwealth's creation.

The Olympics can also be a defining moment in our history—in the one hundredth year of our nationhood, a brilliant opportunity to celebrate our achievements and define our place in the region and the world.
The Olympics will generate economic growth and jobs well beyond Sydney itself.
The IOC's decision was a tribute to all those who worked so hard to put together an outstanding bid.
The Prime Minister and Mrs Keating were delighted to participate in the bid's presentation to the IOC, and were gratified that the Government was able to indicate its material support for the bid.

It is a tribute to the breadth of support for the Games among the Australian community—demonstrated so memorably by the tens of thousands of people who showed their enthusiasm in Sydney on Friday morning.
In a wider sense, Mr President, the IOC's decision is also a tribute to the society we have created here—its social equity, cultural diversity, tolerance and its sophistication and efficiency.
Sydney's approach was set apart from others by its technical excellence and by its commitment to the athletes themselves and to the ideals of the Olympic movement.
All the people involved in the bid deserve the warmest congratulations and thanks of this Senate.
More than that, Mr President, they deserve the continuing support of all Australians—government, business and the community—in the seven years of hard work that still lie ahead of us.
The Prime Minister can say on behalf of the Commonwealth Government that they will have that support.
Mr President

The Prime Minister began by stating that his visit to the United States and Europe took place at a time of great consequence for the world economy—a time when new patterns are being created, and when great decisions are being formed.

Within the next twelve weeks alone we will have the first meeting of the leaders of the Asia-Pacific economy community, we shall enjoy success or suffer failure in the Uruguay Round, and we will have, by the year's end, a surer sense of whether recovery can take hold in Europe and Japan, and strengthen in the United States.
It is a decisive time in world economic affairs, Mr President, and it comes as Australia is achieving greater international recognition.

Sydney's Olympic win reflects this most dramatically, but it is also reflected in Mr Clinton's generous praise of Australia's role in forging APEC, and in the respect accorded to Australia's views in the Uruguay Round as the leader of the Cairns group of fair agriculture traders.
Mr President
There is a responsibility on all of us to recognise that we are in a bigger game—a game with bigger prizes but with new and tougher rules.

SPEECH.PARA: Attorney-General
The Hon. Michael Lavarch MP
Senator Barney Cooney
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Cooney
I refer to your letter of 17 February 1993 to the former Attorney-General enclosing a copy of the Committee's overview Report entitled `The Cost of Justice—Foundations for Reform'.

I generally support all the recommendations but note that they advocate more monitoring and public discussion, including an ongoing reference for the Committee, rather than making any concrete recommendations for reform and improvements to the administration of justice in Australia. I understand that future reports proposed by the Committee will address specific issues identified in the first report.
My specific comments on each of the recommendations are as follows:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 1. The Committee recommends that the Senate provide the Committee with a continuing reference enabling it to monitor and report annually on specific initiatives undertaken to increase access to, or reduce the overall cost of, justice, and on the cost of justice generally.
Response: Supported, though this a matter for Parliament to decide.

Recommendation 2. The Committee recommends that each court, tribunal, legal professional association, legal aid body, law school, legislature and relevant government department report annually and publicly on what that organisation has done to increase access to, or reduce the overall cost of, legal services and litigation. In the context of the recommendation in paragraph 34, the Committee will be examining these reports.

SPEECH.PARA: Response: Agreed. The Attorney-General will write to the key organisations referred to in the recommendation urging that they implement this recommendation. As a result of an earlier recommendation of the Senate Estimates Committee, the Attorney-General's Department, the federal courts and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal already include a section on Access to Justice in their annual reports.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 3. The Committee recommends that the Australian Bureau of Statistics collect and publish, on a continuous basis, statistical material relevant to the legal profession and the operation of the legal system in Australia. The Australian Institute of Judicial Administration should analyse, assess and prepare reports on this information.

SPEECH.PARA: Response: The Australian Bureau of Statistics already has a range of initiatives underway to expand the collection of statistical material relevant to the legal profession and the operation of the legal system in Australia. This includes updating the l987-88 survey of the Legal Services Industry and possibly conducting similar surveys in future years, but not annually. The Bureau has indicated that it is prepared to discuss any additional collection requirements over and above those already proposed for the legal profession. The recommendation has also been referred to the Board of the Australian Institute of Judicial Administration for its consideration.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Recommendation 4. The Committee recommends that it have responsibility for convening a regular legal forum, open to the public, at which representatives of those groups having a significant influence on the administration of the law and the legal system might exchange ideas and proposals for its improvement.

SPEECH.PARA: Response: Supported, though this is a matter for the Parliament to determine.

Finally, I wish to emphasise the importance I place on the role of the Committee not only to monitor change, but to act as a catalyst in shaping public opinion and adding support to existing proposals for reform of the justice system generally.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government's response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, as indicated in a letter from the Attorney-General, the Hon. Michael Lavarch MP, to Senator Barney Cooney, the chairman of the committee, is to be welcomed. It is not to be judged by its length. No committee can complain when the relevant minister agrees, by and large, with all the recommendations made.

PARA.TAB: The first recommendation of that committee was that it be given an ongoing reference to monitor and report annually on specific initiatives undertaken to increase access to justice or reduce the overall cost of it, and on the cost of justice generally. That recommendation is supported by the Attorney-General. He wisely points out that in the end it is a matter for the Senate as to whether it chooses to give its standing committee that ongoing reference. I certainly hope that all members would support such an ongoing reference to the committee. The reason for that is perfectly simple. I presume it is obvious to everyone so it will not take much to elucidate.

All I really care to say is this: we all know that, unless we are very rich or very poor, the opportunities for us to enforce our rights are simply not there. We call them rights, as though we can have them as of right. But, if we do not have the money, we cannot get them. It is a ludicrous situation that is getting worse and worse.

They are not the sorts of sexy law reforms or policy initiatives that are ever likely to hit the front pages. On a one-to-one basis, people do not care about the cost of justice until they need access to it, and then they cannot afford it. It is then that they realise how expensive it is, and they join the band of people who realise what a deplorable situation we are in. It is not something that all Australians appreciate will, in the end, touch them in a very real way. Unfortunately, we have to wait until they are burnt by the legal system, or locked out of the legal system, for them to appreciate that point. Nonetheless, I am pleased that the Attorney supports that recommendation.

The second recommendation was that the committee would contact each of the bodies that might have some influence in this area, and they are very wide-ranging. The cost of justice is not a problem that has been created by one particular group. We play a part in it as a parliament; state parliaments play a part in it; the legal profession plays a part; the judges play a part; and some consumers, who think the justice system should be there as of right for them to access willy-nilly, also play a part.

The sorts of groups included in this exercise would be courts, tribunals, legal professional associations, legal aid bodies, law schools, various state governments and state government departments. What we want to do is get those people to simply indicate on an annual basis what they have done in the past year to increase access to justice or to reduce the cost and what they intend doing in the forthcoming year. It is a pretty simple exercise. It is not some expensive exercise in either time or dollars. It is just a simple report on what they have done.

The purpose of this recommendation is to encourage those groups to focus on what they could do. Every little change mounts up in the end to a massive change across the board. So the purpose of this recommendation is to encourage a continual level of change, albeit at a small pace, and to focus the minds of those groups on the need to do something each year to increase access or reduce the cost of justice. In respect of that, the Attorney says that he agrees and indicates that he will write to some of these key organisations recommending that they go along with and implement that recommendation. The sooner those letters are sent the better, and I warmly commend that response.

The third recommendation related to collection of statistics on the cost of justice by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The Attorney had some things to say. He basically indicated that some statistical material is already collected. The bureau has indicated that it is prepared to discuss what else it could do to get better information. That recommendation has also been referred to the board of the Australian Institute of Judicial Administration for its consideration. So at least there is something happening on that front. What will happen in the end has not been resolved, but at least there is agreement that it is a sensible proposal put forward by the committee so that people in the future have some figures available to them on which they can base policy decisions. Hopefully, in the end this will result in a decrease in the cost or an increase in the access.

The last recommendation made by the committee was that it be given the responsibility of convening a regular legal forum, open to the public, at which representatives of the groups such as those I have just mentioned have the opportunity to exchange their ideas and proposals for improvement. The basis of that recommendation was that it simply is not enough to have individual groups considering these things in isolation. In the end, we will maximise the contribution of each of those groups if they can come together and exchange their views. Often it may be that the procedural activity engaged in by one organisation and the reasons they have not changed in one way or another actually relate to a misunderstanding as to what some other group that they work with requires of them and expects of them. So, if we can organise an exchange of views, it will be very productive.

The Attorney indicates that he supports that recommendation, although he again comments that in the end it is a matter for parliament, including obviously the Senate, to decide whether it would be happy to have such a forum.

I compliment the Attorney on his relatively speedy response to the committee's report and on what he has said in his response. Last but not least, I urge all honourable senators who have not yet had the time to get a copy of The Cost of Justice—Foundations for Reform. This is not an isolated issue that can be targeted to a particular group. In the end the cost of justice affects everybody. In my view, all parliamentarians should at least spend some time perusing this report to see what contribution they can make towards implementing its recommendations and, for that matter, facilitating its spirit.

(b)their structure, operations and community services;

SPEECH.PARA: This is a motion to refer the question of the government's proposed tax increases on credit unions to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration. Those proposed tax increases are contained in the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill 1993. They were formerly within the omnibus bill that the government has withdrawn and redrafted.

PARA.TAB: I think it is fair to say that the industry has successfully, from our perspective, made a case for a Senate committee to examine the government's proposal in this regard. My understanding is that the government's argument for increasing taxation on credit unions is to ensure equity in taxation with building societies. The industry believes that that argument is simplistic because credit unions are structured in ways other than those of building societies. So simply to affect one aspect of business, that is the taxation practice, would not achieve equality.

More specifically, it is pointed out that credit unions do not have the same equity raising capacity that building societies have. Being under different legislation, building societies are able to seek capital through share issues in a way that credit unions are not. Therefore, credit unions have to rely on building up capital out of profit and the taxation on their profits becomes of greater consequence than it is in relation to building societies. The industry argues that one cannot simply equate building societies to credit unions and say that if one provides a similar tax regime then each is being treated fairly.

That argument certainly warrants careful consideration by a Senate committee. The response of the committee might well be that the legislation under which credit unions are constituted should be changed so that they have the same equity raising capacity as building societies. I do not know whether that will be the response of the Senate committee, but it is obviously one option that might be open to it.

This matter could be debated in this chamber but the careful analysis that is necessary of such issues is difficult to be achieved through a debate in this place. Senate committees in the past have demonstrated that they are able to produce information upon which the Senate is able to make a better judgment. Thus, I think this matter warrants that sort of consideration.

The other argument that is put these days is that there are some similarities between building societies and very large credit unions. In fact, many credit unions are of a fundamentally different nature from building societies. I am speaking of the hundreds of smaller credit unions that are often linked to particular industries or particular regional or country towns which are set up on the principle of volunteerism. A small community or employees within a particular industry join together with no profit motive, of course, but to help to provide credit to each other.

We are talking about structures that are fundamentally different from building societies. Because they are small and are often in regions of Australia that are suffering, particularly at the moment, from the recession or the aftermath of the recession, they are vulnerable. Therefore, it has been put to us that many of these small credit unions that fulfil worthwhile community services will not be able to sustain this new taxation regime, which, as I said, is really a taxation regime that has been applied to a fundamentally different type of credit provider, a large and strong building society and one that is able to raise capital through other means.

As a result of these representations, which we in the coalition certainly believe warrant further and careful consideration by the Senate, I gave notice of this motion to refer the bill to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration for inquiry and report on or before 28 October 1993. I really chose the date on the basis of what seemed reasonable to allow the committee to do its job properly. In effect, what I was seeking was approximately a month. It seemed to me that that was warranted because there are so many credit unions in distant parts of Australia and they are often small.

It is my view that they should have an equal opportunity to contribute to this parliamentary process, if that is their wish. To communicate with them, to give them the opportunity to make a submission and to become part of that process, of necessity, takes time.

The committee has to have time to consider those representations, to consider the complex issues of law and taxation and to report back to this Senate. We heard from Senator McKiernan yesterday, in relation to one Senate committee, that he felt the time allowed for consideration of the complex issue of the constitutionality of this package was insufficient for the committee to have done its job in the way that he would have liked it to be done.

The danger in making these references too short is that the work that is done perhaps is not of as high a quality as the Senate has a right to expect. On the other hand, we all know that some committees have considered matters for a long time. Therefore, it seems to me that it was necessary to have a tight time frame. I am also conscious of the fact that for this chamber to deal with the bill it would need the committee's report.

The Senate will be anxious to deal with the government's taxation package at least within the usual time frame for dealing with such legislation. I am advised that the normal time frame for taxation bills arising out of a budget is that they get into this chamber about mid-October. Therefore, it seemed to me that it was not unreasonable for this committee to report by 28 October. The date has been chosen as a balance between, on the one hand, the need for the committee to expedite such a hearing but, on the other hand, a desire for the committee to have sufficient time to do justice to the industry and ensure that its work is of the standard that we require.

In relation to the terms of reference, I have mentioned that, in order to do the job properly, the committee should look at the role played by credit unions in Australia, in particular their structure, operation and community service. By that, I mean the way in which they operate compared with building societies and other credit providers. I am conscious that in many small towns the history of recent times has been that banks have been leaving those towns. They are generally not served by building societies and the credit union is actually becoming more important in the provision of consumer credit than was once the case.

I believe that the committee should also look at the history of the partial tax exemption that the government is seeking to remove. Further to what I said a minute ago, it should look at the treatment of this particular industry in relation to capital formation and the capacity of the industry to continue to provide the financial and community services that it has provide in the past. It should compare the taxation treatment with other like bodies, if they can be identified as like bodies. Basically, the committee should give advice to the Senate as to whether there are still reasons for the differentiation of tax treatment between credit unions and building societies.

I put this reference to the Senate today as a constructive effort to better inform the Senate on what is an important but nevertheless difficult issue in order that the industry and communities most concerned by this new taxation proposal of the government can be properly brought within the parliamentary process. This chamber needs to be fully informed so that its final determination in relation to the bill can be based on sound evidence and careful consideration, rather than what is sometimes the case—insufficient deliberation simply because of the nature of the conduct of this chamber.
