The situation in Yugoslavia is a current example of political, cultural and religious prejudice that we would want to counteract by this declaration in this country. It is important to support the extension of the freedom of religion. It is under threat in Australia. That is why the Democrats will not support the opposition's motion for disallowance.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate is about freedom. It is about how freedom is established and how freedom is best protected. Those of us in the National and Liberal parties are here today because we seek the disallowance of this instrument. We do not believe that it is necessary to assist in the protection of religious freedom; nor do we believe that the underlying philosophy that the government relies on is satisfactory as a means of ensuring tolerance and good relations between different groups of our society. The whole issue is as simple as that.

PARA.TAB: This issue is not about putting up straw men or finding a book and then deriding it and saying that that is the basis of the case. It is not about claiming that people have bullied religious groups. It is not even about counting religious groups. It is much more fundamental than that. It is about how we ensure freedom. Those on the other side of the chamber fall into what is called the positivist camp. They believe that it is possible in this world to create a set of rules and derive everything from those rules. It follows that they say that everything must be legislated for.

Those of us on this side of the chamber differ because we base our philosophy very much on natural law. The fundamental principle, which Senators Panizza, Ian Macdonald, Ferguson, Watson or myself would all agree with, is that everybody should be free, except when that freedom infringes somebody else's freedom. That is the way one has a harmonious society. In a family one does not have to write down all the rules and say, `So and so shall be allowed to do this and so and so shall not be allowed to do that'. One says, `You have as much freedom as you want, provided that you do not infringe other people's freedom'. That precept requires people in the course of their actions to think about how what they do might affect other people.

If one takes the view that the government takes and says, `Everything must be legislated', what one is really saying is that an individual's only protection is a bit of paper which, Mr Acting Deputy President, as you well know, can be ripped up as I am ripping up this piece of paper now. So much for that protection. But when one builds a society that is based on mutual respect, the protections run much more deeply. It is totally ridiculous for anybody to say that we do not in our body of law in this country at this moment have protection for people's religious beliefs. Of course we do. It is well recognised. There have been many cases in many places many times.

It is not as though the proposal that the government brings before the chamber is one that will add to the law. Is it that this proposal will make the legal system function more efficiently? That too is not the case because the body which will be charged with the oversight of these matters is the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission. This is not a judicial body; it does not follow the rules of court that one might find in the Federal Court or the Supreme Court of Queensland or in any of the equivalent courts in other states. It is a body that is not obliged to follow the usual rules of evidence. It is a statutory body, not a judicial body.

What concerns me and those of us on this side of the chamber is that increasingly in this country we seem to be giving to statutory bodies and public office holders the right to hear matters which should be more appropriately heard in courts of law. It is strange that we have in this constitution of ours a prohibition on the establishment of religion. The government says, `We have a proposal that is going to enlarge religious freedom', but the interesting thing is that it gives the power to decide to Commonwealth officers. When one has government deciding on religion one really does have grounds for concern and fear.
I come to this debate with a particular viewpoint. In many respects, Mr Acting Deputy President, I share your religious starting point—just one—of the Roman Catholic Church.

TALK.START.PARA: —And a pretty good one too.

—And a good one too. I know that Senator Panizza is very proud of that as well. But I also come with another view point, which is the other side of my family which has more than a flirtation with Taoism. The question is: are minority religions better protected through the positivist viewpoint or are they better projected through natural law? My unswerving belief is that they are better protected through natural law because at the end of the day they are always dependent under the positivist viewpoint on government. They are always dependent on what the government will let them have. Therefore, they are always dependent upon the goodwill of the government not to take away what they have been given.

PARA.TAB: In a truly free society it should not be necessary to agree to these declarations, to make these pronouncements, but to rely instead on the equality of men and women before the law as the basis for religious freedom.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who writes the law?
—I missed that interjection, senator.
—I said, who writes the law?

—Senator Schacht, it worries me who writes the law because you write the law. Senator Schacht has shown himself in this chamber time and time again to be very interested in prescribing the rights of various groups of people and limiting the rights of the Australian population. Do not forget that this government, which comes before us tonight and says, `We are going to champion the cause of religious freedom', was also the government that came before this Senate during the last three years and said, `We are going to protect free speech by banning it'. That is its idea of freedom and protecting the rights of the individual.

PARA.TAB: Yes, I do worry about who writes the law because it is written by people like Senator Schacht. But what Senator Schacht does not understand—and this is the important point—is that when one has a natural law basis for one's freedoms one does not rely on people like Senator Schacht and the Labor Party to write the law. One relies on the essential equality of men and women for those freedoms and rights. I believe very firmly that the position that the National and Liberal parties have arrived at is absolutely correct. As a representative of our ethnic community, I feel that I would be doing those people a grave disservice if I voted in any other way than the way which has been indicated tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon I rise in support of the motion to disallow the declaration made by the former Attorney-General, the Hon. Mr Duffy, on 8 February this year, the day after the general election was called. This declaration was tabled in both Houses by the government on 4 May. On first reading the declaration appears laudable enough: it is to bring the rights and freedoms recognised by the United Nations declaration, with regard to the elimination of all forms of intolerance and discrimination based on religion or belief, within the definition of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission Act.

PARA.TAB: I am not questioning the concept that everybody has the right to freedom of thought, conscience or religion or that anyone should be subject to discrimination on the grounds of religion or belief. But I am questioning, on behalf of the many concerned church groups and parents who have contacted me, whether or not this declaration could actually restrict the freedoms that we currently enjoy. We have freedoms bestowed through the constitution, our judicial system and the parliaments that we have in this country.

These institutions are not necessarily pre-eminent in many other countries of the world, so these sorts of declarations might be quite appropriate for many countries. But because of the vagueness of the terminology, I question the implications that this may have and the potential for conflict further down the track in years to come.

Among the groups and the constituents who have contacted me is the fear that agreeing to this declaration will destroy the freedoms that we have rather than enlarging the freedoms that are so necessary for all to live without fear of discrimination in the area of religion.

The declaration purports to extend human rights and religious freedom, but no justification has been given by the government for the need to extend the rights that we already have. What is feared most by those who have contacted me is that this declaration will override parental wishes in relation to the religious education of their children. This fear comes from the fact that the declaration is based on a UN declaration in which the clarity of meaning has been sacrificed for the sake of compromise. One of my colleagues in the House of Representatives aptly said that the UN declaration is `a series of vague, ambiguous and potential contradictory provisions'.

I do not want to reiterate why the UN declaration is vague. My colleague Senator Vanstone and others who have spoken in this debate on our side have already explained the problems in these areas, but I would like to reiterate the problem provided by the provision within the UN declaration dealing with the religious education of children. I thank my colleague Mr Daryl Williams for his very lucid explanation of this in the other place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension for dinner, I was quoting my colleague in the House of Representatives Mr Daryl Williams QC who said that the UN declaration was a series of vague, ambiguous and potentially contradictory provisions. I now want to take this opportunity to explain why I agree with the assertions of Mr Williams.

PARA.TAB: The United Nations Declaration on the Rights of the Child and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights require that the state parties to the covenant undertake to have respect for the liberty of parents and legal guardians to ensure the religious and moral education of their children in conformity with their own convictions. In a similar vein, article 5(1) of the UN declaration provides that parents and legal guardians of children have the right to organise the life within the family in accordance with their belief or religion and bearing in mind the moral education in which they believe the child should be raised. Meanwhile, article 5(3) of the UN declaration provides that the child shall be brought up in a spirit of understanding, tolerance, friendship amongst peoples, peace and universal brotherhood, with respect for freedom of religion or belief of others, in full consciousness that his energy and talents should be devoted to the service of his fellow man.

A parent concerned to educate his or her child in accordance with the parent's religious commitments could well find that the tenets of his or her religion are not in conformity with these particular requirements. The apparently absolute rights given to parents to ensure the religious and moral education of their children may appear to be enshrined in this UN declaration. But the point I wish to make is that it is inconsistent with article 5(2) of the declaration. This article states that, while every child shall enjoy the right to have access to education in the matter of religion or belief in accordance with the wishes of his parents or legal guardians, he shall not be compelled to receive teaching in religion or belief against his wishes. `The best interests of the child' is the guiding principle.

It is this very phrase, `the best interests of the child', which I put to you, Mr Deputy President, opens the door for the overriding of parental wishes in relation to the religious education of their children. Many Christian groups, parents and churches are concerned that, as fewer and fewer families within society are embracing the once strong Western European Judaeo-Christian traditions within their families, these groups in the long term actually could become a minority. In the extreme case, members of our society could declare that the so-called Christian education and the transmitting of Christian ethics and values that occurs within these families could be regarded by others within society as not being in the best interests of the child.

I know that this is the extreme situation and that many would say that this would not occur in a country with freedoms such as we have in Australia—guaranteed by a judicial system, by the parliaments around the country, including this parliament, and the constitution—but would occur only in places with a regime such as that in, say, the former communist USSR.

The point that I am making is that the present HREOC act gives us freedom of religion. The vague definitions of what is religious freedom and what is in the best interests of the child really need very careful consideration. Therefore, I believe that any proposal for domestic legislation seeking to protect or promote religious freedom must be viewed with the greatest of care. The consequences of this declaration in practical terms have been aptly expressed by Bishop Daily, the Bishop of Sandhurst. In correspondence to my lower house colleagues he noted as one example:

SPEECH.PARA: Non Catholic Students attend Catholic Schools, and under this article they could maintain that their Religious beliefs are not catered for, also they could maintain that they will not abide by that Schools regulations with regard to Christian principles, and could maintain they are being coerced.

Amongst his many other comments he finally states that, effectively, governments could make state and church education systems one, with no religion taught in schools. Possible reasons that could be given are: that no one religion covers all beliefs and that religions, therefore, have no place in school curriculums. This is a view that has been put in certain states of the United States.

PARA.TAB: This is a fear held not only by Catholic parents—and I ask my good friend Senator Barney Cooney, a man of tremendous tolerance and religious conviction, to consider this aspect. In Tasmania I have been approached by members of many of the Protestant churches as well. This very week, in fact, I intend to present another petition from 150 signatories who are prominent church people within my own town of Launceston and who are concerned about this declaration. They believe it could restrict the parents' right to oversee the religious education of their children. In addition, I have a file several centimetres thick of letters on this issue which have steadily been delivered to my office over the past few months. Many of these letters have five to 10 signatures. So permeating right across society there is this fear or concern that this is probably not necessary in Australia.

Overall, I would say that several hundred constituents throughout Tasmania have contacted me with regard to this issue. These people are concerned. The possible loss of parents' right to educate their children in their religion is not regarded lightly by many constituents or, indeed, by me. I know that many will say that I am citing the extreme position. But the point to make is that, when the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act is examined, it can be noted that it already incorporates significant statements on the issue of religious freedom. There is no need to extend that freedom, as far as we are concerned, in Australia. It may be necessary in other countries, but it is not necessary here.

The commission already has ample power to promote the concept of religious freedom and to investigate infringement of that freedom by the Commonwealth or, indeed, by its agencies. Therefore, I contend that there is no need now to extend through this declaration the definition of human rights, particularly with regard to religious freedom; and that this chamber, therefore, should disallow this declaration. But I look forward to the informed comments of my colleague, the deeply religious senator across the way, the honourable Barney Cooney.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Watson for those comments. It is very useful to look at the terms of this motion—and I am reading from the speech by Mr Williams, the honourable member for Tangney in the other place. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House—
that is, the House of Representatives—
(a)recognising that everyone should have the right to freedom of thought, conscience and religion;
(b)recognising that it is essential to promote understanding, tolerance and respect in matters relating to freedom of thought, conscience and religion;
(c)noting that on 8 February 1993 the Attorney-General—
and I interpose here that that refers to the Hon. Michael Duffy, whom I consider to be one of the great Attorneys-General not only of this country but of the common law world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you giving him high praise?
—Because he deserves it. Might I also say that his team won the grand final on the weekend too, but that is quite incidental to this. The motion continues:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . declared under subsection 47(1) of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986 that the Declaration on the Elimination of All Forms of Intolerance and of Discrimination Based on Religion or Belief proclaimed by the General Assembly of the United Nations on the 25 November 1981 (resolution 36/55) is an international instrument relating to human rights and freedoms for the purposes of that act;
The motion then points out the only objection to the declaration being allowed. It says this:
(d) noting that it is desirable that there be appropriate opportunities for public consideration and parliamentary debate of the declaration—
disallows the declaration by the Attorney-General.
The contentions in paragraphs (a), (b) and (c) would lead to the conclusion that the declaration should be allowed by this house—in other words, that the motion for disallowance should be defeated.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the strategy that was used to have this declaration disallowed. The only basis for disallowance is the argument that there was no appropriate opportunity for public consideration. In other words, the motion itself does not contain any provision saying that there is anything wrong with the general thrust of what this declaration does. The declaration in itself is not attacked; the only thing attacked is the fact that there has not been an appropriate opportunity for public consideration. So debate in this house about other matters—that there is uncertainty and that the declaration may lead to all sorts of dire consequences—does not relate to the motion.

To be fair, the honourable member for Tangney, Mr Williams, discussed these other issues. But these other issues are not raised in the motion. In his speech, Mr Williams said: The opposition accepts that the ministerial declaration does not of itself make the UN declaration part of Australia's domestic law.

SPEECH.PARA: He accepts that proposition. In other words, the declaration does not in any way introduce into the domestic law the United Nations Declaration on the Elimination of All Forms of Intolerance and of Discrimination Based on Religion and Belief. He continued:

The UN declaration does not impose obligations on citizens as a statute does. The opposition also recognises that the powers of the Human Rights Commissioner contained in the HREOC Act in relation to investigating conduct that constitutes a breach of human rights are, in practical terms, confined to the actions of the Commonwealth and its agencies.

So all the declaration does is put forward propositions with which, I hope, everybody in this chamber would agree. The only practical effect it has in relation to anything being able to be enforced is in terms of the Commonwealth and its agencies. So it does not go, for example, to issues of relationships between members of a family. Mr Williams went on to say:

PARA.TAB: Accordingly, it is accepted that some of the more extreme fears that have been voiced, and in particular those which suggest that the UN declaration operates to curtail the religious freedom of individuals, are difficult to sustain. Nonetheless, there are compelling reasons why the former Attorney-General's declaration should be disallowed.

SPEECH.PARA: But the fact of the matter is that this motion attempts to disallow a declaration that does not have general application throughout the community, which does not in any way interfere with the way the domestic law operates, but which does contain great propositions that we would have hoped everybody would agree with. It is very difficult, given that situation, to see why this declaration should be disallowed.

PARA.TAB: Mr Williams went on to say this:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is not bound at international law to comply with the terms of the UN declaration, nor is it bound to incorporate its provisions into Australian domestic law.
I want to quote the following paragraph in particular:

PARA.TAB: Its adoption in 1981 means little more than that the principles sought to be stated in the declaration were accepted by Australia as a step in the process of endeavouring to reach a formal international consensus on the subject of religious intolerance and discrimination.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Williams uses that as an argument against the declaration and in favour of the disallowance motion. I would have thought that statement is an argument very much in favour of allowing the declaration and for voting against the disallowance motion. What Mr Williams said is that Australia is joining with the rest of the world in an endeavour to reach a formal international consensus on the subject of religious intolerance and discrimination.

PARA.TAB: If we vote against the declaration, we will, according to the propositions put forward by the shadow Attorney-General, Mr Williams, be voting against Australia helping to bring to fruition international consensus on the subject of religious intolerance and discrimination. By voting against this, we will be, on the very argument put forward by the shadow Attorney-General, rejecting a proposition that could help spread religious tolerance and anti-discrimination amongst the world as a whole.

Let us be in no doubt about what will be the effect of voting to disallow the declaration. On the analysis of the shadow Attorney-General, Mr Williams, we would be voting down a step in the process of endeavouring to reach `a formal international consensus on the subject of religious intolerance and discrimination'. What he is really saying is that he does not want that to happen but that there is uncertainty in the way the declaration is framed. Anything is uncertain. For example, section 92 of the constitution, which states that interstate trade will be absolutely free, is uncertain. This has been shown to be the case by the High Court, even though the meaning seems to be apparent at first glance.

It could be argued that laws out of which uncertainty can be teased should be rejected. But on that basis, most legislation that comes before any parliament could be rejected. Mr Williams asked, for example, what is meant by `appropriate charitable institutions'—an expression used in part of the declaration. What does that mean? I would have thought that meant charitable institutions of a good quality; that one cannot get out of ones obligations under the declaration by setting up an institution which is inferior and really cannot be used for the purpose for which it is intended. In my view, that is quite clear. In any event, a court would have no more trouble in interpreting that than it would have in interpreting most legislation that comes through this place.

It seems to me that this is the same sort of expression that people talk about in relation to, say, corporation laws. We are talking about laws being written so that they are not as precise as they might otherwise be; a fuzzy law setting out principles and the courts being left to decide things in particular circumstances. If fuzzy law is all right to guide corporations in this country, why is it not all right to guide the sort of conduct that we all instinctively know is right—that is, that there ought to be religious freedom and that people should not be persecuted for their beliefs?

Mr Williams went on to tease out of the HREOC legislation and the declaration an apparent conflict. With respect to Mr Williams—a great lawyer—that is again taking a very technical approach. The courts and people in society generally know instinctively how balances are to be struck in legislation that is apparently contradictory. It is only contradictory when it is read in a very black letter way. Mr Williams says that the declaration might allow religious bodies to promote unacceptable practices involving mutilation of the body. He states:

SPEECH.PARA: In societies observing other religions, females are accorded inferior status and rights. Indeed, religious beliefs and practices which effectively make women and children second-class citizens almost certainly conflict with existing equal opportunity and sex discrimination legislation.

That is probably right. Any sensible person would say that if there is freedom of religion, it is not a freedom to mutilate women; it is not a freedom to treat certain sections of society as second-class citizens. It means that we all should be entitled to the deeply held beliefs we have. Towards the end of his speech, Mr Williams says:

The government should amend the HREOC Act to allow for examination of international instruments prior to their being declared in relation to other functions of the commission. The government should also undertake to educate the people of Australia about the United Nations, its role in Australia and the impact of its instruments on Australian law. The government should also seek to educate Australians about the functions of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. The government, through failing to keep the people of Australia informed about these matters, is responsible for causing widespread concern in the community about this United Nations declaration and the effect of the ministerial declaration under the HREOC Act.

I understand the shadow Attorney-General to be saying, `There is really nothing wrong with this declaration', in spite of what has been said by his colleagues on the other side. He is saying that there is nothing wrong with this declaration, but that it has not been properly explained. That is consistent with the way in which the motion before us tonight is put forward; the only objection is that there has not been opportunity for public consideration of the declaration. The two things that come out of what Mr Williams says are: firstly, that there has been a lack of consultation; and secondly, that there should be more education of the people of Australia about how the United Nations works, how these declarations work and how the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission works. Those are all procedural matters.

PARA.TAB: The content of this declaration is not taken to task. The issue of whether or not it is properly framed is not really a matter going to its substance; it is a matter that goes to the way it is expressed. That seems a most slender basis for rejecting this declaration. It seems to be agreed by the shadow attorney-general that the sentiments in the declaration are magnificent. Nobody could argue with that. It allows for freedom of religion, freedom of thought and freedom of conscience, and we are going to disallow the declaration on the most slender of grounds. We are going to cast aside a declaration which was adopted in 1981 by the Fraser government—a government of the coalition. Mr Williams says the declaration took 19 years in the drafting. It has been around since 1981. People understand this; they have surely discussed it. It has raised great issues. Yet tonight it will be rejected and, no doubt, that will be the end of the matter.

The occasion of this declaration was at the request, as I understand it, of Sir Ronald Wilson. This has been spoken about again and again. He was President of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, a deeply religious man who had a distinguished career as a justice of the High Court. It was his suggestion that this declaration be brought in in the context of the Gulf War. His concern was that the issues surrounding the Gulf War may have an impact on how people of the Muslim faith were treated in this community. It would seem to me that we ought to pay great respect and great attention to what he said.

The High Court has been criticised in recent times but it has made decisions which establish the principles upon which we live in this society: freedom of expression in the political ads case; people accused of crimes should be entitled to legal representation; the right of people accused of criminal charges to a jury; and that ministerial decisions should be made correctly and fairly, applying the principles of natural justice.

The High Court, that third arm of government, is conscious of the needs to preserve rights in the community. It is about time this chamber and the parliament generally had discussions about issues of human rights and human principles. There might be less need for the High Court to protect our civil rights were we in parliament to put forward and at least give legislative form to some of these rights. If we were to do that, we would vote against this disallowance motion. That would at least be a declaration—that is all it would be—about the principles inherent in the declaration before us.

If the declaration is voted down, it will be another example of the interests in this parliament simply centring on economic matters. Many of those economic matters are based on economic rationalism. An eminent judge in Victoria, Mr Justice Vincent, who today addressed the law conference in Hobart said, `There is not only economic rationalism, there is social rationalism' which means that those great aspirations that we should have as members of society are put aside in the interests of efficiency, whatever that may mean.

A vote in favour of this disallowance motion would be another example of the social rationalism that is pervading society—and perhaps this chamber—at the moment. This is a chance to give expression to the great aspirations we feel without introducing them into domestic law and without in any way affecting the relationships between members of a family or between one member of society and another. It has only a practical effect on the Federal government and its agencies. On the other hand, its passage would allow a great educative impact to occur in society where religion is, in my view, still of great importance, still the basis of our society and something we should give attention to. In his book Civil Liberties in Australia Geoffrey Flick says:

The common law, it would appear, does not regard discrimination on racial or religious grounds as contrary to public policy. Thus, by way of example, it has long been the practice of some testators to impose a condition in their wills stating that a beneficiary is to forfeit a benefit conferred if he should marry a person "not of the Jewish faith", or on ceasing "to profess the Roman Catholic religion". Such conditions may fail if no meaning can properly be ascribed to the terms employed by the testator or if no efficacy can be given to the application of the condition to the facts. But according to the House of Lords in Blathwayt v. Baron Cawley a condition which is not so uncertain as to be unenforceable is not contrary to public policy.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a need for some education to take place within the community to remove that very significant element of racial and religious discrimination. Perhaps I ought to withdraw the word `racial' because that is not relevant to the present debate. There is a need to remove that too great an element of religious intolerance that still operates in the community and to introduce tolerance and respect for people in terms of their freedom of thought, conscience and religion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to support the remarks that have been made by members on our side of the House today. I do so not because I am a person with the eminent legal qualifications of Senator Cooney, and not because I do not believe in the particular international instrument that was declared under subsection 47(1) of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986 on 8 February this year, but because I fear that a lot of people in our community are very concerned about this matter. In the six years that I have been in the Senate I do not believe I have received more correspondence than I have received from all over Australia, from people of different religious beliefs, even from the Catholic bishops, saying that we should disallow this declaration.

PARA.TAB: Senator Cooney said that we are voting against the declaration. I believe that, if this disallowance motion is carried, we will not be disallowing the instrument because the instrument has already been declared. We are trying to stop this particular declaration being administered in Australia by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.

A lot of the people who have been coming to my office and writing to me look upon some things in life as basic rights. One of them is religious freedom; they see it as a birthright. I believe the last thing they want is for the government, no matter how well intentioned it may be, to interfere with that birthright. As has already been shown by well intentioned moves of the government in the past—trying to show the way to the rest of the world—the signing of these UN conventions and treaties has caused all sorts of troubles in our country. I believe that is why we will never see the United States of America—that great nation with all the freedom it has—signing these United Nations treaties and conventions.

I know that Senator Harradine, my colleague from Tasmania, has pointed out to this place more than once his concern about the thousands of conventions and treaties that this nation has signed—treaties that, whether we like it or not, have certain effects on this nation. As a Tasmanian, I can tell honourable senators that Tasmanians have certainly realised just how binding some of them are. The external affairs powers were used to the detriment—some would say to the benefit—of Tasmania; nevertheless the state's powers were overridden.

The average man in the street is fearful of these declarations that are continually being made. While we might say it is the best thing they can have and it is good for them, it is a little like the GST argument. We tried to tell people that it was the best tax available and the best for them, but in the end they were frightened of it. I believe this is a similar type of thing; whilst it may look good on paper and it may be the perfect set of words, they are concerned because it interferes with what is to most people a basic right and a basic freedom.

This declaration is further evidence of the government's attempt to divide our nation. As I said, there are two matters which are considered sacred by most Australians: one is the constitution and the other is religion. In recent months we have seen the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) seeking to divide our nation on both these issues. He has proved that he will do anything to keep the nation's mind off the real problems at the moment—that is, the disastrous state of our economy, unemployment and the failed budget.

It is quite clear to me, as I said earlier, given the amount of correspondence, telephone calls and whatever that I have received—not from organised religious bodies, but from people from all facets of society—that the majority of Australians do not want Australia to have anything to do with this declaration. It is also clear that neither the government nor the Democrats give a damn about what the majority of Australians think. If we proceed with this declaration, it will be against the wishes of the Australian people. It will show the Australian people that the government and the Democrats are more concerned about their own agenda than they are about the wishes of the community.

I believe that the definition of intolerance and discrimination contained in the declaration is an unacceptable constraint upon the practising of religion in this country. I say that not just from the viewpoint of the Christian religion, but from the viewpoint of all those who practise their various religions in our country. That is a key point because the adoption by Australia of the Declaration on the Elimination of All Forms of Intolerance and of Discrimination Based on Religion or Belief would appear to presuppose that we have some problem in that regard.

From the opportunity which I have had to examine the religious freedoms available in other nations, I do not think there is any doubt that this country is one of the most tolerant in the world, so why would we want to change it? Australia is a multicultural nation where people live side by side, person to person and religion to religion. It is my view that the only religious intolerance which exists in Australia today is the type of inherently evil intolerance which cannot and would not be eradicated by 20 United Nations declarations.

As an open-minded and fair nation, it is clear that there are parts of the declaration with which we would all agree. For instance, we all recognise that everyone has the right to freedom of thought, conscience and religion. We already uphold the view that no-one should be subject to discrimination on the grounds of religion or belief. But there is a concern—and I believe it is a genuine one—that if we incorporate the United Nations declaration into the definition of human rights in the HREOC act, we will not protect religious freedom in Australia; rather we will limit it. This point has been made continually by all my colleagues.

We need to recognise the fundamental right which Australia has to conduct our affairs as an independent nation. We also need to acknowledge that the declaration is, at best, a vague and confusing instrument. Having listened to Senator Cooney tonight, I believe that, whilst he did not say it, in the back of his mind he probably believes that.

We have only to recall the many different interpretations which have flooded our offices to recognise the confusion which this declaration causes. It is a declaration which was 19 tortuous years in the making. Like all such declarations, it was not the best answer, but rather an amalgam of what each participating nation was prepared to agree to.

Like you, Mr Acting Deputy President, I attended the IPU conference here a couple of weeks ago. If you attended the drafting meetings on motions that we wanted to put down dealing with different nations, you would know just how much give and take there was to come to an acceptable form of words. Who is to say that, at the end of the day, the meanings of those acceptable forms of words that we agreed to cannot be misinterpreted? The motion about Bosnia-Herzegovina was agreed to only as a result of bowing to the wishes of some of the Iranian people who were of a different religion from the other people who were putting forward another point of view. I believe that is how these declarations are arrived at. As I said, they make look very good on paper, but it is the way that they are interpreted at the end of the day which is important.

As an example we do not have to look any further than the international convention on human rights which we signed. It had the effect of causing the birth of the racial discrimination act in our country. It is because of that particular act that we have got ourselves into the mess we have with the Mabo problem. I will not argue the rights and the wrongs of it, but one has been a consequence of the other. Because of that racial discrimination act, we now have the Mabo situation.

My colleague Senator Watson touched on the rights of the child convention. I believe that is another one which is coming up in the future, so I will not discuss that tonight. The point is that, even in this place, the former Minister for Justice, who is now either in the Hague, the Holy See or in between, had a couple of reservations about that particular declaration; yet the government did not see fit to change it. That is the reason we will want that convention disallowed. It is not because we are against most of it; it is because, at the end of the day, parts of it can be seen in a different light.

The declaration has special and concerning ramifications for our schooling system. This has been pointed out by more than one speaker tonight, but I will go over it again from my own point of view. The situation could easily develop under the declaration where students attending a school of a particular religion could claim that their own religious beliefs are being ignored. They could also claim that any attempt to have them conform with the school's principles of behaviour amounted to religious coercion. The declaration could also lead to a claim of discrimination by minority religious groups over larger religious groups over matters as straightforward as a government grant, for instance. These are some of the concerns that have been coming forward from independent schools. We have an independent school system which relies on government funding and we do not want to put in measures in a way that could interfere with the fair continuation of that system.

As an aside, I was lucky enough to attend a school in Hobart—and Senator Harradine would be aware of it—which is the only Quaker school in the Southern Hemisphere. That particular school, at which I was a boarder more years ago than I wish to remember, was my first taste of different religious groups. On Sunday mornings we would all trot off to our own particular churches. There were some six or eight churches ranging from the Methodist Church through to the Catholic Church, the Anglican Church and the Presbyterian Church.

The fact of the matter is that we attended a Quaker school and we abided by Quaker beliefs. But if one of the minor religious groups attending that school took this particular convention to its utmost conclusion, it could take issue with being taught by a particular person who is of another religion. Its students may say that they had been discriminated against because they would not obey the particular method by which they were being taught or the particular religions that they were asked to go along with. I suppose one could say that they do not have to attend that school and that they could go to another school where the religion might suit them. If that was to happen, I think it would create more divisions in the community and would alienate people in a way that we do not wish to happen.

In summary, the HREOC act already covers religious freedom. The definition is vague and inconsistent and the impact of this convention that we are trying to disallow is unclear. It is not clear whether the declaration would condone religious beliefs or practices which Australians might find abhorrent. I am suggesting that the HREOC act should be amended to allow greater scrutiny of these international instruments because I believe that until now they have caused great concern amongst Australian voters. If we do not come up with a better system of scrutinising them, they will continue to be a problem to members of both sides of the chamber, I suspect. I suggest that this might be a good idea in theory, but in practice it will be a disaster and just cause more division in our community when we should be pulling together in all sorts of ways. I look forward very much to hearing the comments of my Tasmanian colleague Senator Harradine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is considering the following motion:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the Senate:

PARA.TAB: (a) recognises:

TAB.TAB: (i) that everyone should have the right to freedom of thought, conscience and religion, and

PARA.TAB: (ii)that it is essential to promote understanding, tolerance and respect in matters relating to freedom of thought, conscience and religion; and
(b) notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i) on 8 February 1993 the Attorney-General declared under subsection 47(1) of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986 that the Declaration on the Elimination of All Forms of Intolerance and Discrimination Based on Religion or Belief proclaimed by the General Assembly of the United Nations on 25 November 1981 . . . is an international instrument relating to human rights and freedoms for the purpose of that Act, and

PARA.TAB: (ii) it is desirable that there be appropriate opportunities for public consideration and parliamentary debate of the Declaration.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) That the declaration by the Attorney-General, dated 8 February 1993, of the United Nations Declaration on the Elimination of All Forms of Intolerance and Discrimination Based on Religion or Belief, made under subsection 47(1) of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986, be disallowed.

I read the motion out because I think that senators ought to realise what they are going to vote upon. I have listened to the arguments that have been advanced against the motion. I have not found them convincing, nor do they really address the motion.

PARA.TAB: Surely we all believe that everyone should have the right to freedom of thought, conscience and religion? They are the most fundamental of human rights. I am not suggesting for a moment that those people who initiated debate in this area as far back as 1960 or 1961 believed other than that the rights to freedom of thought, conscience and religion were the most fundamental of human rights. I am sure that they believed that these were fundamental human rights and that action by the United Nations would advance and promote these fundamental human rights. We have to realise that these freedoms are the inherent right of every human being. Why? It is because human beings are created by God and the relationship between human beings and the creator is the most fundamental of all. Therefore, we obviously all agree that this is the most fundamental of human rights.

It is most important that this right not be misinterpreted by a non-elected organisation. I do not suggest for one moment that an elected organisation is the repository for a perfect interpretation of such instruments. Far less do I agree with what is regarded by authoritarian regimes such as the PRC to be human rights—that is, those rights that are determined by law in that country. These human rights are inherent, universal and inalienable. They cannot be taken away by states or by human rights and equal opportunity commissions and they cannot be given away by the bearers of those rights. Those rights are needed to ensure the full flourishing of the humanity of each individual who bears those rights.

I do not suggest for one moment that the persons who formulated this declaration were ill-intentioned; on the contrary. However, as I see it, there are problems with this declaration. It appears to attempt to qualify the provisions in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights which was agreed upon by the United Nations in 1948. It appears to qualify provisions in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. I believe it is a bit like what happened in Vienna in June of this year when a 28-page document on human rights qualified, in my view, very substantially the very simple six page Universal Declaration of Human Rights which was adopted in 1948. Certain provisions of the Declaration on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination based on Religion or Belief are vague and open to the possibility of misin-terpretation. That is the key to the problem. The motion moved by Senator Vanstone calls for a public debate on this declaration before it becomes an attachment to legislation.

I realise that once the declaration becomes an attachment to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act it will bind only the Commonwealth and Commonwealth agencies. However, it will be there and it will be able to be interpreted by the commission in a manner that may be quite contrary to what an individual reading of the declaration might otherwise suggest. It has happened before. Tomorrow, when we come to deal with the rights of the child convention, I will give the Senate an example of where a misinterpretation of the provisions has led to actions by the international monitoring committee which I believe are quite contrary to the intentions of the drafters of that declaration.

I believe that the onus is on the government. Why the rush? Why did the Attorney-General sign the instrument which meant that this declaration would be part of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act one day after the election was called?

TALK.START.PARA: —It was brought here on 8 May with a whole heap of other stuff.
—As Senator Calvert indicated, it was brought in here on 8 May with a considerable number of other instruments.

PARA.TAB: I remind the Senate that I have had a notice of motion on the Notice Paper for some considerable time. It appears on page 9 of the Notice Paper of 17 August. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: That a standing committee of the Senate . . . be appointed to consider all treaties laid before the Senate, and any other treaties to which the committee may have access, and to report in respect of each such treaty: (i) whether Australia should undertake to be bound by that treaty if that treaty is not already binding upon Australia, and (ii) the effect which Australia's being bound by that treaty has or would have upon the legislative powers and responsibilities of the Australian States—
The definition of `treaty', which is included, states:

. . . means any agreement or proposed agreement in writing between 2 or more countries which imposes or would impose rights and obligations upon those countries and which is or is intended to be binding upon those countries—

I acknowledge that the declaration that we are considering now is not a treaty, but it is presumably the precursor of a convention down the track. I think it is important under those circumstances to give proper consideration to this matter. If my motion were adopted, I believe that a standing committee of the Senate would be capable of receiving advice and submissions from a whole range of people. That would be the civilised and proper way to go about this matter.

PARA.TAB: There is a considerable amount of confusion in the minds of the public on this matter. People who have come to Australia from authoritarian or communist countries are concerned. They have memories of their own countries which had beautiful constitutions enshrining freedom of religion. One example of this is the former USSR. But, of course, the interpretation by the state of those provisions left very much to be desired.

I am not suggesting at all that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission will, in fact, interpret the declaration in such a way as to give it a meaning which is not immediately obvious. What I am saying is, why the rush? Why does not the government allow a full and free debate on this question, as is envisaged in the motion which is before us?Why not adopt this motion which will enable community debate and discussion to take place? I would like to see submissions from people as to how they think the declaration will be interpreted. I would also like to hear from the government as to how it thinks it ought to be interpreted, because it must have some views on the matter.

I have seen the correspondence between Mr Hannaford and the Attorney-General, and I am not convinced that Mr Hannaford does not have a point. I think he may well have a point. If that is the case, then we should have that matter clarified. Mr Hannaford happens to be the Attorney-General of the biggest state in Australia. I assume that he has had advice on this matter. If that is the case and there is any doubt about it, let us proceed in the manner that is suggested by this motion.

Let me make it perfectly clear that I believe, and I am sure the original framers of this declaration in 1962 believed, that religious freedom is the most fundamental of all freedoms. But because people have various views about the interpretation of this declaration, we must be absolutely certain that we preserve that freedom.

Not one person from the government has suggested that this declaration is necessary so far as Australia is concerned. It certainly is necessary so far as some other countries are concerned, but it does not appear to me at least to be necessary for Australia. For the declaration to be now made part of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and for the commission to include it in its educative process will require some sort of interpretation by the commission of the articles of the declaration. I believe that we should act with caution on this most fundamental matter. Therefore, I will support the motion that was originally put forward by Senator Calvert and the opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to conclude this debate. We have been debating this matter for some four hours this afternoon. I think what the debate has shown is the degree of isolation that the other side still manages to dwell in. We have seen this afternoon that although Australia has changed enormously and fundamentally over recent years and although the declaration which has been adopted by the government is one that not only has universal support internationally but also has wide ranging support within Australia, there is still one body of thought in this country that cannot adapt to new ideas and cannot adapt to change.

PARA.TAB: Some 120 or 140 different ethnic communities make up the fabric of our society. Forty-three per cent of Australians have their roots directly overseas and 25 per cent of them come from non-English speaking background countries. But it seems like the opposition has not recognised this fundamental change in our society.

We have a policy which not only tolerates diversity but also lends encouragement to that diverse nature of our society. We are a modern, tolerant, multicultural society. We recognise diversity; we recognise the rights of minority groups to express, enjoy and celebrate their differences, religions and traditions. It seems that although this has happened, it has missed the Liberal and the National parties.

What we have is a system whereby we support non-English speaking background people being part of this society. We have an inclusive approach; we do not have an approach which is exclusive. In the context of a society which tolerates rather than oppresses, which recognises rather than dismisses, which encourages rather than represses, we had in 1991 an initiative from former Justice Wilson concerning the effects of the Gulf War on the fabric of our society. There was concern about the effects that that war might be having on those who wanted to express their religion, to enjoy their Muslim faith. As a consequence of that, Justice Wilson raised the idea of the government endorsing this declaration.

As I say, Australia has changed. Leading jurists in this country have recognised that change, but the opposition still remains barricaded to the past. One can ask oneself why in 1981 it was the then Liberal-National party government that voted for this particular instrument internationally; why it was part of a universal and unanimous position internationally to adopt this instrument; and why some 12 years later the coalition has gone backwards. Have the Liberal and National parties gone backwards or was it hypocrisy at the time? That is a stark choice for those who may be interested in this debate to try to discern. They either did not believe what they were doing in 1981 or, as Malcolm Fraser said of the Liberal Party just before the election, in economic thought the party has gone backwards. It is obvious in social thought that it has not progressed at all—it has even gone backwards from 1981.

It was the Liberal-National party government which put up Australia's hand at the United Nations in support of this instrument some 12 years ago. But it is the opposition that continually shows itself to be isolated in terms of the public debate, the social debate and the changes that are going on in this society. As I say, the instrument was adopted unanimously by the United Nations in 1981, and it has not let it rest since then. Earlier this year in the United Nations Commission on Human Rights, under its agenda item on the implementation of the declaration, a resolution was passed calling on states to ensure that their legal systems provided adequate guarantees of freedom of thought, conscience, religion and so on. The UN has maintained an interest in this matter as have people in this country.

Once again, as in 1981 when the instrument was adopted unanimously, this year a resolution encouraging member states to implement measures to embrace the instrument was co-sponsored by 38 countries and adopted without a vote. If one wants to see to what degree the opposition is isolated on this matter, one only needs to look at the list of those countries who urged this measure. Those countries not only included Australia, Canada and Ireland but also the United Kingdom, Northern Ireland, and the United States of America. Who are those opposite left with? Who are their friends internationally? There is not one member state. There was unanimous adoption in 1981 and unanimous encouragement now for governments to embrace this international instrument.

As I said earlier, in 1991 Sir Ronald Wilson took the initiative in 1991 and wrote to the Attorney-General on 4 March of that year initiating discussion for the adoption of this instrument. This letter talks about the passage of a unanimous resolution at the World Conference for Religion and Peace Consultation in Melbourne in 1991. This shows how isolated the opposition is. I think the following passage from Sir Ronald's letter should be placed in the Hansard record—just remember that this was in the aftermath of the Gulf War with the problems that Muslim communities were experiencing at the time. Sir Ronald said:

SPEECH.PARA: There was an interesting sequel to the presentation of my paper on human rights from a religious viewpoint. During question time,—
This is at this international conference—

I was asked from the floor whether I thought it might be possible for the Commonwealth government to give consideration to including the 1981 UN Declaration on the Elimination of all Forms of Intolerance and of Discrimination based on Religion or Belief in the commission's jurisdiction by making a declaration under section 47 of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986. I answered in the affirmative, whereupon there was spontaneous applause. The meeting then resolved unanimously to that effect and I was asked to bring the suggestion to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission.

Once again there is universal support internationally, but members of the opposition in their normal way tie themselves to the past and barricade themselves in a vacuum divorced from the changes in our society here and in society internationally.

PARA.TAB: Sir Ronald Wilson then raised the matter with the Attorney-General. That then led to the consultation in 1991 that Senator Harradine now demands. There was some 18 months to two years of consultation. How much more consultation does one have to have before one gets stagnation through consultation? Mr Duffy then embarked upon a process of consultation. High level consultation was appropriate having regard to the commission's existing responsibilities. Attorney-General Duffy wrote to all states attorneys-general in March 1992. He received replies from all states, and only Western Australia and New South Wales had objections. We have since seen those objections to be without substance and as a consequence the government embraced the instrument.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said they were without substance?

—I am asked `Who said they were without substance?'. Well, let us look at the Western Australian concern. Attorney-General Berinson raised a concern, but in doing so he recognised that there would not be a legal problem unless the original declaration itself was enacted by the Commonwealth. There is intention to do this. Unless one does so, there is no problem for Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: We have another by-product in the debate this afternoon. Opposition senators have been running hot with their arguments and their fear campaign. What does the shadow Attorney-General say about the basic point that those opposite are concerned about? SPEECH.PARA: It could not be clearer—

It is important to reaffirm it in an instrument which consolidates the jurisprudence on this particular matter. That is the second reason why we are proceeding with this particular provision. The effect of the provision will be to ensure that HREOC will not only ensure that the Commonwealth government, its laws and its practices, conform with the declaration but also will have the function of promoting religious tolerance in the community.
