DEBATE.TITLE: HEALTH AND COMMUNITY SERVICES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 27 May, on motion by Senator Richardson:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on only part of the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill, my concern being directed to parts 3 to 5. My colleague Senator Patterson is intending to address those parts of the bill which relate to aged care matters.

PARA.TAB: The bill is largely about correcting mistakes that were found in earlier legislation. It is yet another in a litany of bills which demonstrate the government's appalling management of its legislative program. Legislation is rushed through this chamber, indeed rushed through both chambers, without adequate scrutiny, and then—I know my colleagues agree with me—six months later the government comes crawling back to this parliament with corrections saying that it is very, very sorry but it has got to `fix this up'.

The changes in this particular case are relatively minor. The most substantive of them relates to the secrecy provisions in the Health Insurance Act. As honourable senators would be well aware, departmental officers often receive requests for information about public and private hospitals. The information sought includes names and addresses of hospitals, bed capacity, kinds of services provided, teaching status and whether the hospitals are public or private. The incredible thing is that under current legislation this important information is protected, although it is readily available in the public domain. Obviously, it is a nonsense.

Clause 16 allows an authorised officer to release certain specified information about hospitals. Given the availability of this information in the public domain, there is no good reason for opposing this clause. As I said, there is little of substance to debate in this bill.

What is important to debate—and this bill gives us an opportunity to do so—is just what has happened to the health care of Australians under this government. The budget has given us some more examples of missed opportunities and the mismanagement by this government of the health care of Australians. We have all seen the back-pedalling by the government on a number of measures. But, even with the changes that appear likely to go through, this is still a regressive budget.

Following pressure from the coalition, the later protests of the Australian Democrats and the Greens and, finally, the caucus revolt, the government announced its intention to rescind the decision that optometrists' fees would no longer be claimable from Medicare. This government went to the last election fighting about the preservation of Medicare; it claimed that the opposition was ready to dismantle Medicare. What sort of government would now have the hide to come in here and start to dismantle Medicare? That is exactly what happened with the optometrists' charges. Under that change which was proposed from 1 November, average Australian families would have been forking out almost $50 for a first consultation with their optometrist and another $25 for a follow-up consultation. Yet, at the moment they pay nothing because over 90 per cent of optometrists bulk-bill.

Those changes that were announced in the budget constituted a tax on spectacle wearers of $50 a year. Now that that measure has been dumped, there is a $90 million hole in the health budget. We do not know how the government proposes to address this funding shortfall; we will be very interested to find out. It is certainly going to make for some explanations at some stage or other. I think we will be waiting for some time for an answer to that question because the government continues to address some of the very important issues in the health portfolio, and that is but one of them.

The budget has failed to tackle in any substantive way the real problems in the health portfolio. I draw the attention of honourable senators to the principal savings. They are built on a false edifice. Claims that this budget will reduce medical fraud and overservicing are quite unconvincing, particularly in the light of the government's past performance. The National President of the AMA, Dr Brendan Nelson, has questioned the extent of the savings, as have I.

Let us turn to the reduction of hospital queues. Senator Richardson appears to be conducting a sleight of hand. The government made a great play during the election about how it would do something about hospital queues and, as I recall, there was a promise of $100 million over four years to reduce those queues for elective surgery. These are the queues where your grandmother or your aunty is waiting for a hip operation, or uncle is waiting for a prostate operation; they are waiting in pain for months or years for those operations. So the government, which had been in charge of the health budget for 10 years, turned around at the election and said, `Okay, quick, quick; we'll throw $100 million at it over four years'. If we look very closely at the budget, that is not what the government is doing at all.

Last year in an existing program the Labor government committed $48 million to the states and territories to reduce waiting times; this financial year it is allocating only $12.4 million. In a new program this year the government has allocated an additional $12.4 million. So the old program has been reduced by about $36 million and the new program will receive $12.4 million. That is where the sleight of hand comes in. It appears that there will be $23.2 million less available for getting hospital beds in the private sector than last year. So much for the election promise of $100 million over four years. It was not much of a promise anyway because, as Dr Nelson has pointed out, buying private beds for public patients will exacerbate the decline in the number of people who are privately insured. With not enough money coming into the system through encouragement of the private sector, increased rationing is inevitable.

I think Senator Richardson has acknowledged now that he will not be able to buy those beds in the private sector. So the money the government will spend, which is less than we expected it to be spending, will be spent on studies. This is a government which delights in spending taxpayers' money on studies. It has consultants here and consultants there. The government tends to spend quite a bit of the money in the last couple of months of the financial year, I have found. Some of the anecdotal evidence which has come to my attention from various departments is that these things get filed away at the end of the financial year. It has something to do with not losing the funding for the next year, I understand.

Let us look at other matters. The budget rations the access of members of the general public to pharmaceuticals. They face a higher safety net and when they reach the net they will no longer receive drugs free. Senator Richardson has also recently announced a review of the Medicare benefits schedule. This is a longer term measure since it is to occur over a period of two years starting later this year. He has also said that he will be taking a package of measures to cabinet late this year aimed at addressing the problem of a plummeting number of Australians holding private health cover.

But the trouble is that, on purely irrational and blind ideological grounds, Senator Richardson has ruled out the measure which would best address this problem—tax incentives to encourage greater participation. It is clear to Blind Freddy and his dog that tax incentives are the best way possible to allow low to middle income earners to afford to stay in private health insurance. The number of people who are on relatively low incomes and who are clinging to their private health insurance like grim death is really very surprising. It is an indication of how important it is to many Australians; yet this government does not recognise the financial difficulty that they are under in trying to maintain that private health insurance.

Senator Richardson is prepared to sock the wealthy; he is prepared to give a stick to those wealthy, like the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) who is not prepared to pay for his own private health insurance but insists on using the public sector and taking beds from those who cannot afford private health insurance. Senator Richardson is prepared to deal with people like the Prime Minister; he is not prepared to recognise that people on low to middle incomes want desperately to stay in private health insurance; and he is not prepared to help them through tax incentives. It is a nonsense. If Senator Richardson were to go down any main street in Australia he would find people saying to him, `Please, help us with tax incentives'.

I would be interested to know just what role Senator Richardson played in the decision to increase the price of leaded fuel by 10c a litre as originally promised in the budget, because the government has defended this increase on health grounds—a concern for children and for the level of lead in their blood. In my view that is a totally specious argument. It is simply a massive tax grab which hurts low income earners more than anyone else. In a searing article just after the budget was brought down, Margo Kingston, the columnist in the Canberra Times, gave the lie to this defence. In referring to the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, she said:

SPEECH.PARA: Why, he was asked, was he raising the price of leaded petrol above that of unleaded, a tax targeted at the poor who couldn't afford newer cars? He used children to try to sell that one. Apparently it's the children of the poor who suffer most from lead poisoning. Apparently that means their parents should pay extra. He said he was encouraging the poor to buy non-leaded petrol cars.

PARA.TAB: How could they, when he'd devalued the value of their current car overnight, increased their petrol prices, and raised the price of newer cars? If he really cared about children's health why didn't he use the funds raised for a rebate to convert old cars to non-leaded petrol?

SPEECH.PARA: I think that expresses it extremely well. The government cannot parade in these hypocritical clothes trying to pretend that that tax grab on fuel is anything to do with the health of children. It is clear to all Australians that the government has been motivated by the need for increased revenue rather than a commitment to improving the health of Australians, in particular, Australian children.

PARA.TAB: The minister, as part of his budget, pointed out that there is a need for services for people to die with dignity. It should also be pointed out to the government that Australians would prefer to live with dignity, rather than the continuous struggle to keep their heads above water as a result of this government's mismanagement.

I conclude by pointing out that more than a quarter of all households in Australia are now mainly dependent on welfare. While the major issues at the head of this government are the republic and the flag—the modern version of the bread and circuses to distract a people in trouble—one million people are without a job; 100,000 of them are waiting in queues for elective surgery; and more than a quarter of households live on welfare. No wonder the suicide rates among our young are rising. The health and the life of this nation are in jeopardy.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I will look briefly at the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill 1993. The Australian Democrats basically have no problem with this legislation. The legislation makes a number of minor amendments, quite a few of which are simply to correct drafting errors. There are two main areas of change. The first is the creation of criminal offences within the Aged or Disabled Persons Care Act.

PARA.TAB: These offences relate to the giving of false or misleading information in support of various applications and submissions made under the act. These applications and submissions are basically for the purpose of obtaining financial assistance from the Commonwealth government or, indeed, for cancelling the right of someone to financial assistance. It has been assumed that false information given under the act came within the ambit of the general provisions of the Crimes Act; however, this has been challenged and the government has now moved to clarify this situation.

The bill makes it clear that it is an offence to give false or misleading information in certain circumstances under the Aged or Disabled Persons Care Act. The Democrats do not have any problems with this move. The government should be able to rely upon the accuracy of information it is given when it is making decisions about the suitability of people to provide aged care services. Other recipients of public funds, for example, social security recipients, are expected to provide accurate information to the government and can be prosecuted if they do not. I cannot see any reason for the providers of nursing homes, hostels and other aged care services not to have the same obligation.

The second major change is that this bill contains a number of amendments to the National Health Act dealing with nursing homes. The one which has caused some concern in certain sections of the industry is the requirement upon nursing home proprietors to keep records which can verify their entitlement to Commonwealth subsidies for a period of seven years. Again, this is in line with similar requirements placed upon corporations under the taxation law and we do not have any problems with requiring recipients of Commonwealth funds to keep such records. Proprietors should be able to produce valid records in support of their claims, and I do not see that this is in any way onerous or unfair.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the remarks of my colleague Senator Newman in relation to the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill. The changes are minor. It is another example of the water pouring in through the holes in a colander, with the government inadequately trying to put its fingers around it to stop the water pouring out. The reason this is occurring is that the fundamentals are wrong. They have always been wrong. They will continue to be wrong, because the government does not have the wit to understand what is going wrong.

PARA.TAB: Senator Richardson, the new Minister for Health, has been racing around the country meeting with every interest group around the place trying to come to terms with it. I have no doubt that Senator Richardson is a person of ability and that he will do his best.

The reality is that, since this government has been in power, the people that were prepared to put money into the system are no longer prepared to do so. It is bankrupt. It is as simple as that. The levy was increased to bring in what appeared to be an increased sum of money and all it did was make up for the numbers that have gone out. Only a little over a third of the population in this country pays any Medicare levy. People do not realise that.

When we speak to people and ask, `Do you pay a Medicare levy?', they say, `Yes, I pay my Medicare levy'. How much do they pay? It can be as little as $50 a year. They pay their Medicare levy but, because the income level at which the Medicare levy comes in is higher than the taxation level, they may pay as little as $50 a year. They feel that they are entitled to the benefits that they get. The average expenditure on health care for people in Australia is now about $1,700 a year. Because some people pay $50 a year they believe they are entitled to it. That is what they have been sold by the government—`It costs you nothing. Be in it, mate. You are entitled to it. You are entitled to free health care'.

Since this government has been in power the 75 per cent of the population who were prepared to be covered by private insurance has decreased to less than 40 per cent. In my own state of Queensland, the figure is down to 30 per cent. That may be rock bottom level. The same 30 per cent who are privately insuring are paying the Medicare levy. The rest is coming out of taxation. Any system that is funded by taxation is bust. It is bust because we have an aging population; two-thirds of the health care dollar is spent on people over the age of 60. It is bust because of the cost of technology. The only answer which the government has is rationing.

Senator Richardson discovered a couple of months ago that one has to wait two years at the Royal Hobart Hospital—he believes it is unconscionable—to get a hip replacement. I have news for him: it is a three-year wait at the Royal Brisbane. In Queensland, the mortality rate whilst waiting for coronary bypass surgery has now exceeded the operative mortality rate. There are people dying on the waiting list. We will not hear about it. People do not like going to the press to complain about this. They are grieving. They are not going to create a fuss about it. The people affected most are those people who are not accustomed to complaining. They have been browbeaten to the extent that they are not willing to come forth.

In Queensland we have had wholesale desertions of doctors from the public hospital system. The answer from the government: `They are money grabbing doctors, getting out of the system; they can make more money outside'. There are 2,000 specialists in Queensland who contribute to the public hospital system for about one-third of the rate that they could earn in the private system. Do we ever hear them being praised? There is never a mention of them. They do not get a mention at all.

The system is bankrupt. Senator Richardson has been floating balloons all over the place that say, `We should privately insure. We have to increase the money people pay to privately insure'. The answer? Give them rebates or tax deductions. Interestingly, the new, brave, Democrat Clinton plan will allow tax deductibility for private insurance in the United States. The big difference is that 80 per cent of premiums in the US are paid by employers. In essence, there will be a compulsory levy in the US which will come out of the pay packets paid for by employers. That is not an answer either. The answers are there; it is as simple as `get out'. Senator Richardson does not have to go running around the country to find out from everybody what the answer is. It has been as plain as a pikestaff for the last 15 years. We should encourage people to go into private insurance, to accept responsibility for their own health and to contribute towards it.

There has to be a symbiotic movement between the public and the private sectors. They exist. To a large degree the public sector contributes to health care through major surgeries, such as liver and heart transplantations, which none of us could afford because of their intense cost. The private system can do it equally as well, and in many respects does it better. As a Queenslander I am proud to say that Queensland has the best private hospital system in Australia. For example, more gastroenterology is done in the private hospitals in Brisbane than in the public hospitals because of the long waiting lists there, and the standards are higher. The only machine that can mash up kidney stones, to use the vernacular—a lithotriptor—is in a private hospital in Queensland and public hospital patients have to be transported across to have the procedures done there.

That is the success of private medicine—it aims at excellence. The American system has gone along that way but at tremendous cost to the community. Nobody in their wildest dreams would think that we should go along the same track.

Allied to this are all the other pressures that Senator Richardson is finding out about now. He will run up against the rock that every Labor health minister has run up against and that is the ideology that the state will provide. He will come to the same conclusion. It will be interesting to see how he goes. There will be some sort of deal, much along the lines that the employer will pay, and there will then be an added cost to business.

These changes in this bill in relation to pathology are of a very minor nature, backed by the royal colleges. It will be interesting to see what Senator Richardson does about fraud and overservicing. I have challenged him on numerous occasions. That started off at $400 million, it is now down to about $25 million, and during estimates, the government admitted that it does not really know—it is just a figure. It will be interesting to see what it actually is. I put the government on notice that in a year's time I will be asking that question.

Of course there are other problems, including the maldistribution of medical personnel, the shortage of doctors in the country and the low rate of return for some specialties. A taxi driver in Sydney earns more in a weekend than a obstetrician—or a patient—gets refunded for having a baby.

TALK.START.PARA: —It doesn't take as long.
—It takes nine months; did they not tell Senator Woodley?
—He delivers it; he doesn't have it.
—He looks after her.

—He or she looks after the lady, because there are many women obstetricians. I was trying to show the analogy that the female obstetrician may have the baby. The woman has antenatal care for nine months, there is the postnatal care and then the baby is delivered, whether it be by caesarean section or by natural delivery. That care is given for the princely sum of just over $400. As was said in the Sydney Morning Herald recently, that is what the average taxi driver earns on a weekend in Sydney.
—How much do they pay for their litigation?
—Ten thousand dollars is the litigation fee for an obstetrician. Half the obstetricians in Australia have given up obstetrics in the last five years.

PARA.TAB: These are the problems that are facing Senator Richardson. He is now on a fast learning curve. There are many other problems. He should know them because this side of politics has been telling him about them since their fruition. These are the problems that are facing him and I do not believe he has any solution.

The national health strategy was the last solution. It went for three years—from 1990 to 1993—and cost the taxpayer $4 million. Half a million dollars went to one consultant—a former departmental officer—to write one book on the problems confronting the public hospitals. I wish I was a consultant and got paid $500,000 to tell the government what the problems are in the public hospital system. I did it for nothing in my maiden speech. An amount of $286,000 was given by the federal government along with a matched grant from the state governments. Great if you can get it.

Getting back to the national health strategy, at least Senator Richardson has had some wit by cancelling it. It was going on forever, producing papers, all of which have gone nowhere. I put on notice today a motion to ask him what improvements have occurred as a result of the national health strategy—a three-year inquiry which cost over $4 million of taxpayers' money. I can tell him. We have gone backwards. The waiting lists have got longer, there are no solutions and there have been no improvements. We will see what he comes up with. TALK.START.PARA: —It was a very great honour for me to be invited by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Faulkner) to represent the opposition and join the delegation of veterans to visit France and Belgium to commemorate the 75th anniversary of the ending of the First World War. It was also a personal pleasure for a number of reasons, not the least because I have a deep interest in military affairs.

PARA.TAB: The involvement of the Australian Commonwealth Military Forces, the AIF, in Belgium and later in France was the foundation on which Australia's very successful military capability was built. In my judgment, Gallipoli does not have its correct place in Australia's military history. Gallipoli tends to be seen as the most important campaign by Australian forces in the First World War. It certainly is the most publicised.

At Gallipoli, the AIF fought with incredible determination and courage. It was the first major campaign of a new and untried force. But it was a force that had no military experience to draw on. While it fought valiantly and courageously and with great enthusiasm, victory did not come its way. In a sense, the military lessons to be learned by the Australian Army as a consequence of the Gallipoli campaign were limited.

It was in Belgium in the Ypres Salient in 1916 and 1917 and in the Somme Valley in 1918 that the AIF learnt its skill at arms and became the finest infantry force fighting in that war. It learned there what needed to be done to be successful in the field of battle. From Passchendaele and Messines in Flanders, from Fromelles, where the 5th Division was almost wiped out, Pozieres, where the 1st and 2nd Division lost more killed and wounded than Australia has ever lost before or since in one area, and at Bullecourt lessons were learnt that culminated in the brilliant successes from March 1918 to final victory in November 1918.

In March 1918, the first German breakthrough occurred. The German army drove westward with the objective of capturing Amiens and splitting the British armies in the north from the broken and exhausted French armies in the south. The five Australian divisions rushed down from the north, held the advance of the German armies for all time when they were within site of Amiens. After the German breakthrough was held, the Australian divisions, with the Canadians, the New Zealanders, the British army and, finally, the newly arrived Americans, drove eastward until the German forces capitulated.

Through those eight or nine months leading up to the armistice, the combat abilities and successes of the AIF took second place to no other army. The AIF became the dominant force in the Somme Valley. After the main breakthrough, the German army had been halted. In April, the Germans captured the high ground in which the town of Villers-Bretonneux was situated. In a brilliant night action, mounted immediately after the seizure of the town and with only hours of preparation, Brigadier Glasgow's 13th Brigade and Brigadier Elliott's 15th Brigade retook Villers-Bretonneux. From there, the five AIF divisions, fighting together, displaced the German army from the Somme Valley through to the Hindenberg line.

Hamel, a small town just east of Villers-Bretonneux, was one of the first of those victories. In a sense, Hamel is the site of the first occasion when modern land warfare tactics were used. By this time, the Australian Army was operating under its own leaders. General Monash was now the Australian Corps Commander. Monash, a civilian soldier and engineer from Melbourne, was the outstanding general of the war. Of very high intelligence, he had a flexible, innovative mind and, though older than many of his contemporary generals, he was always ready to develop and apply new tactics after he had meticulously thought through every detail.

My father was an officer in one of the infantry battalions. I remember him telling me on many occasions how Monash used to conduct his briefings. Every detail was meticulously and lucidly laid out and every officer present, even the most junior, was encouraged to comment on the plan.

Hamel was of great interest. The infantry advanced behind a complex artillery fire plan which lifted at set intervals before the advancing waves of attacking infantry. That had been done many times before. But in Hamel there were two new innovations. Monash had seen a demonstration by the Tank Corps of the new mark V tank. After the disaster at Bullecourt in April 1917, when the earlier tanks failed completely with huge casualties for the Australians, the armoured corps or the Tank Corps, as it was called then, was persona non grata with the AIF. Monash saw the greatly increased capabilities of the new mark Vs and saw the opportunity of using them with infantry to break the barbed wire entanglements and suppress the deadly machine-gun posts. He integrated into his plan the use of armour and infantry working together.

Lawrence Wackett, from 3 Squadron of the Australian Flying Corps, had developed a technique of parachuting machine-gun ammunition into the battlefield into the hands of the advancing infantry. The supply of ammunition, particularly machine-gun ammunition, in an advance was a major problem. It all had to be carried by soldiers over broken ground under fire. In putting these elements together, Monash developed the tactics of the modern battlefield and broke, albeit still at a high human cost, the dominance of barbed wire and fixed defences.

Hamel also marked the first occasion that the American forces fought with Australians. Some of the early American units were attached to the 11th Brigade for experience. By a strange coincidence, the battle of Hamel took place on 4 July.

Against the terrible background of attrition in that war, where battles usually lasted many days, weeks or months for negligible gains in territory and casualty lists that ran into thousands, Monash planned the battle of Hamel to take only 90 minutes. The 11th Brigade of the AIF completed this task in 93 minutes. From there, the AIF advanced inexorably up the Somme Valley, taking all before it until victory was assured.

In these campaigns of 1918, the Australians displayed enormous courage and self-sacrifice, strong battle discipline, flexibility in planning and high intelligence. The success of 1918 was the anvil on which the abilities and reputation of the Australian Army was forged. When thoroughly trained, adequately equipped and properly led, those achievements of 1918, which made the Australian Army second to none in the field of combat, are still possessed by the Australian Army.

The achievements of 1918 were bought at a terrible price. Australia's population then was under five million. Over 330,000 Australians volunteered to fight in the armed services. One out of every two soldiers was wounded, some more than once. Over 60,000 died on the field of battle or directly from wounds sustained in battle. It was a huge price to pay for a young nation.

To commemorate these great events, the government decided to send a delegation of veterans, war widows and descendants of veterans to visit the battlefields of France and Belgium. Fourteen veterans were selected, along with seven widows of servicemen who served in the First World War and two legatees, one whose grandfather and the other whose great grandfather had served. The delegation was led by Senator Faulkner.

As I said earlier, it was a great honour for me to be invited. My father had served as an infantry officer in one of the battalions of the third division. He served in all the campaigns of that great division from its first days to its last.

The central focus of the delegation was the veterans themselves. The youngest was 93, with the great majority 94, 95 or 96. What marvellous people they were. They were all very alert and lucid. Intellectually, they belied their years. Their enthusiasm for everything, the long hours of travel and engagements, their unfailing high spirits and goodwill with never a cross word or complaint, was an inspiration. I must say that I had some worries beforehand about how they would handle the fatigue and the friction that is inevitable on such a visit to the other side of the world. There was a great deal of activity packed into only 10 days. They loved every minute of it.

The story is told of one of the veterans on the Gallipoli visit. When someone expressed concern to him that the visit might be too stressful and he might not come back, his response was, `Well, that does not matter. We nearly didn't come home the first time we were at Gallipoli and everything after that been a bonus'. The same spirit clearly moved those on the Western Front delegation.

The success of the delegation—and by any standards it was very successful—rested on the planning of the entire operation. The overall planning was performed by Admiral Ralph from the Repatriation Commission. Drawing on the experience gained from the Gallipoli trip, Admiral Ralph did a marvellous job.

The heart of the success of the visit in a real sense was the medical planning under the aegis of Dr Graham Killer, the Chief Medical Officer of the Department of Veterans' Affairs. It is a daunting task to accept the responsibility for the welfare of 14 veterans in their mid-90s and seven widows of their former comrades of similarly advanced years. But the medical planning really was superb. Everything was thought of; everything was thought through.

Three medical officers travelled with the delegation. As well as Dr Killer, Dr Glenda Powell, a specialist gerontologist from Greenslopes Repatriation Hospital in Brisbane and Group Captain Roger Capps, a specialist in aviation medicine, formed this team. They were supported by 11 carers—men and women from the repatriation hospitals and from the air force—who provided the nursing services.

In another life, I spent a considerable portion of my time working in hospitals and I say without hesitation that the devoted attention and the quality of service of the carers for their wards could not have been improved upon. It was exemplary—nothing was too much trouble—24 hours a day from departure in Sydney until we returned. The proof of that lies in the fact that everyone in the delegation stepped off the plane in Sydney. That was an enormous achievement.

Sadly, about 10 days after we returned Hugh O'Donnell passed away, but I can confidently say that he never regretted embarking on the pilgrimage. Like all his comrades, he viewed it as a privilege and obligation to pay homage to those who did not return in 1918. It was a privilege for all of us to have had his company for those 10 days.

The delegation was accompanied by an army contingent. This consisted of a military band plus a guard drawn from regulars and reservists under the command of Colonel Vale. Their presence and their ceremonial drills put a very professional seal on all our engagements.

The engagements on the program tended to follow a standard format. All the major battlefields of the AIF were visited, as were the memorials to the five divisions and other significant Australian memorials. Usually a guard was posted, an historical address on the significance of the site to Australia was read by Dr McKernan from the Australian War Museum, wreaths were laid by members of the delegation, and the Last Post and the Rouse were played.

On 11 occasions, battlefield plaques created by Dr Ross Bastiaan were unveiled. These bronze plaques consisted of a sculptured relief map of the region together with a text in English and French explaining the history of the battles in the area.Dr Bastiaan, a dentist in private practice in Melbourne, is a notable public spirited Australian. He has rendered great service to the Australian nation with his plaques. Visiting Gallipoli some years ago, he was surprised to find that there was nothing available to explain to the thousands of young Australians who visit each year in increasing numbers what happened on the site. They come because they know the name, but visiting a battlefield 50 or 75 years after all the detritus of battle is gone means that they simply cannot reconstruct what took place. So on his own initiative he started a program of placing large bronze plaques in over 70 sites around the world—Gallipoli, Singapore, Thailand, Papua New Guinea, France and Belgium to name a few.

Dr Bastiaan has taken it on himself to raise the funds from private industry to pay for these plaques. As well, he designs the plaques himself and oversees all the work involved in fabricating, transporting and erecting the plaques on their sites. He has performed a very great service to the Australian public. His plaques will serve future generations of Australians very well as they seek to understand this nation's achievements.

On reflection, many memories come flooding back. The ceremony at the Arc de Triomphe on Sunday where there was a joint French and Australian wreath laying ceremony at the French national memorial; the ceremony at the Australian memorial at Fuilloy, Villers-Bretonneux; VC Corner, Fromelles, the only Commonwealth war grave cemetery I know of where there are no headstones; marching behind the Australian Army band and guard with colours flying down the

SPEECH.PARA: road from the Cloth Hall in Ypres to the Menin Gate, a road that every one of the five Australian divisions traversed, and the intensely moving service that followed that at the Menin Gate; and finally the ceremonies at the 2nd Division memorial at Mont St Quentin and later at Peronne.

PARA.TAB: I would like to finish with a human story about that 2nd Division memorial at Mont St Quentin. Mont St Quentin is the dominant physical feature in that area and was taken by the Australians in what General Rawlinson, who was the British 4th Army commander in whose army the Australian corps was placed, described as the finest feat of arms in the war.

With the 3rd Division on the north flank and the 5th on the south, on 29 August the 5th Brigade, which was only at about a third of its strength, fought up the hill without any artillery or armour support and displaced the crack German 2nd Prussian Guards Division. They were later displaced from the hill themselves by a counter attack from the Germans. The 6th Brigade regained the mountain and they were eventually replaced by the 7th Brigade—the three brigades of the 2nd Division.

One of the veterans we had in the party was Robert Comb from Canberra. He was a Lewis gunner in the attack. Most of the members of his section were killed in the attack. He single-handedly overcame some German machine gun posts and was awarded a Military Medal for his action. At the ceremony, Dr McKernan read an address, wreaths were laid a battlefield plaque was unveiled. When the ceremonials were over, the crowd mulled around. Bob Comb walked over by himself, stood by the plaque, looked out over the valley which dominated Peronne, which was taken shortly after Mont St Quentin, and without saying anything to anyone pulled out a can of Fosters and drank it, savouring every drop. He did not say a word to anyone, but it was quite apparent that this was something that he had planned for years and he got enormous pleasure out of it. Those of us who knew of it, also got enormous pleasure out of his pleasure.

In conclusion, I congratulate the minister Senator Faulkner on his conduct and the outcome of the delegation. He led it with great distinction. His officers in the Department of Veterans' Affairs can all take high praise for the success of the delegation.

I have not named everyone who was involved, but I think those officials who came along all made a contribution to the outcome; and they made a contribution to the limits of their ability. The visit was executed without any hitches at all. It gave great pleasure and satisfaction to those few who still survive from their 330,000 comrades. The French, as the host nation, gave generous support and reaffirmed those links forged over 70 years ago between our two countries.

Above all, it was the experience of a lifetime. We few who were in the party had the opportunity to join in the fellowship and partnership with those 14 out of 330,000 of the AIF and traverse once more the scene of their great defeats and losses and their ultimate victories. It was a great privilege to share the fellowship of these men, these living links with those immortals of the AIF who forged Australia's military history.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the Senate's edification, I will present another instalment in the series of my attempts to spread some information about the hazards of chemicals in our society. I think I should forewarn honourable senators that the information I am about to share this evening deserves to have a heading of environmental illness and what is called multiple chemical sensitivity, often abbreviated as MCS. The fact is that chemicals are about profits, and therefore politics. It is also an issue that impacts on humans and the environment creating a need for regulation, control and repair. The human consequences of toxic chemical exposure in Australia must urgently be addressed.

PARA.TAB: Announcements from universally respected institutions place the situation in its true perspective. An investigation by a body of 20 prominent American scientists resulted in the Winspread report, which came to light in Wisconsin in the United States in July 1991. Its focus was chemically induced alterations in sexual development—the wildlife and human connection. The paper discussed the reproductive viability of many species which had been exposed long-term to toxic chemicals. Its conclusion expressed concerns for the future of the human race. The gravity of their comments may well have influenced the World Health Organisation to declare that toxic chemicals and the illness they cause are the plague of the present decade. That claim was made in the Commission on Health and Environment's report entitled Our Planet—Our Health, which was presented at the Rio Earth Summit in 1992.

Nevertheless, there are many reasons why there is a marked reluctance to accept the notion of chemically induced illness. It has huge implications for governments, employers, insurance companies, chemical manufacturers themselves, their agents and advertisers, and those who have to pay sickness benefits, workers compensation and pensions. There is also a perception that doctors who prescribe drugs which often come from the same sources as many toxic chemicals do not take the issue of chemically induced illness seriously, or they regard all illness as a purely medical problem.

Another problem is the lack of media attention. The media exploits chemical spills, fires and explosions as newsworthy, but the human element that remains long after the drama has ended merits little attention. Quiet suffering does not sell newspapers or increase TV ratings.

In this country considerable amounts of money have been allocated to the treatment and research of a large variety of debilitating illnesses. Yet MCS, with symptoms that are equally serious and equally incapacitating, has not attracted one cent. In Australia it is studiously ignored, despite huge economic ramifications. By contrast, in the United States, Congress has allocated $ 1/4 million for research into MCS to be coordinated by the National Centre for Environmental Health Strategies in New Jersey. Attempting to evade this issue is costing our governments, our employers and our communities far more than coming to terms with chemically induced illness and doing something positive about it.

MCS may result from long-term low level exposure to chemicals or single dose acute exposure. Chemicals which cause MCS are endless in variety and include pesticides, household and industrial chemicals, solvents, cleaners, prescription drugs, formaldehyde and cosmetics. Petrochemical substances are frequently involved.

On becoming sensitised by exposure to one chemical, people develop adverse reactions to a whole range of other substances, such as other chemicals or even food and drinks. The natural environment may also present problems with pollens and grasses to which there was no previous reaction. This sequence is well documented in the literature and is called the `spreading phenomenon'. The single trigger may cause many so-called allergies to emerge. These are all symptoms of multiple chemical sensitivity.

The mainstream medical profession suspects that MCS is the result of a viral infection, although to date research has found no germs which have been linked to the onset of the disease. This has not stopped the medical profession from typically inventing a variety of other names to describe its symptoms, including myalgic encephalomyelitis, chronic fatigue syndrome, post viral syndrome, 20th century disease, yuppie flu and so on. I am sure that honourable senators have heard some of these trendy names that have been applied. Many of these names have strong clinical overtones. It is as though the medical profession, by inventing this menu, seeks to confine the illness to the traditional medical domain.
Physical manifestations of MCS range from profound fatigue, aching joints and muscles, to full scale gastric, circulatory, respiratory and musculoskeletal involvement.

TALK.START.PARA: —It sounds as if the sufferer may have been in the Senate for too long.

—That may be so. The symptoms of MCS, I hasten to add, often also involve generalised pain and mood swings; concentration and memory lapses are frequently reported, as are dermal ulceration and rashes. Many chemical victims tell of recurrent flu-like episodes linked to periodic contamination of their environment with substances to which they become sensitised. Toxic agents, after doing their damage, often leave the body with no residual signs, except in the case of substances like organochlorines, lead and some other elements which may remain in the tissues permanently or for an extended period.

PARA.TAB: Many classically trained doctors focus on germs as a cause of an illness, as they have long done, and often write off their MCS patients presenting with a cluster of symptoms as hypochondriacs or malingerers because no germs can be found. Chemical victims are either sent packing or told that they are depressed, and have even been sent to psychiatric hospitals for electroconvulsive therapy. Sometimes they are diagnosed as suffering from the mysterious myalgic encephalomyelitis or chronic fatigue syndrome. Such a diagnosis leaves patients in a state of limbo while the search for the missing germs or viruses continues.

Patients diagnosed as having ME or chronic fatigue syndrome should instead be suspected of suffering from MCS. If that were done, questions asked about chemical exposure at work or home, or about chemical sensitivities, would suggest a new holistic approach. In Australia, unfortunately, this approach has been overlooked in the quest for orthodox answers.That is even worse because prescription drugs often unwittingly exaggerate the MCS patient's symptoms.

There is no cure except complete isolation from the source of contamination, additional rest when necessary, a stress free lifestyle, sufficient vitamin supplements and a diet free of all known allergens. This allows a prospect of recovery with differing degrees of improvement according to the individual affected. Improvement lasts up until the next exposure, whereas sensitisation is enduring and many patients report that such sensitisation is in fact life altering.

In 1991 at the Wistar Institute in the United States, researcher Dr Elaine de Freitas discovered, during a research project, that many of the ME, or myalgic encephalomyelitis, patients she was investigating were, coincidentally, sensitive to a variety of chemicals. This in itself gives rise to the question: which came first, the chicken or the egg? That was the sort of situation that she was faced with.

In 1989, the New Jersey Health Department in the United States, concerned by the spread of environmental illnesses, commissioned a study by Professor Nicholas Ashford and Dr Claudia Miller into MCS. Their report won the World Health Organisation's Macedo Award in 1990. It is a landmark text in the recognition of the disease and the concerns this addresses have been echoed elsewhere in the United States and Canada, but not in Australia. In 1989 the Californian Attorney-General included MCS in recommendations in the final report on disability. Similar recommendations have also been recorded in the San Francisco mayor's draft disability report in 1990.

In the United States environmental illness and its consequence, MCS, has been accepted as a legitimate medical condition and is listed in the social security manual. This means that people with MCS are able to obtain income support, a pension or sickness benefit. Medical recognition in the United States is more readily available than in Australia because they are 13 years ahead of us with regard to research in this matter. We are in fact retracing ground already covered with technology that is out of date. I seek leave to have the remainder of my speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Clinical ecology is accepted as soundly based science by the US medical and scientific professions, and as a result they have available greater numbers of clinical ecologists.

The US Housing and Urban Development Department is required to provide special non-toxic housing to applicants suffering from MCS. The Canada Mortgage Housing Corporation is moving in this direction. It is evident that the problem is being dealt with more seriously overseas than it is in Australia, where it still has not found its way on to the political agenda.

Environmental Illness and MCS can be likened to an iceberg, showing only the visible tip of its immensity. The US National Academy of Sciences has estimated that 15% of the American population is adversely affected by chemicals which should alert Australian authorities to the gravity of the situation, particularly since many chemicals long since banned or restricted overseas, are still freely being used here. Some of these are DDT, Vapan, Prothiopos, Halaxyfop-methyl. MCS deserves recognition, acceptance and appropriate treatment like any other illness or injury, particularly as its effects are more enduring and far reaching than many other illnesses.

People recover from mechanically caused injuries and are left with an attenuated, but otherwise healthy organism. This is not so with MCS, whose victims must contend with years of ongoing illness, in addition to the initial organic damage which exposure to toxins have wrought. Their wounds are hidden, but they are very much in need of support, encouragement and social justice.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin with a confession. This afternoon I missed an opportunity to take note of a report, so I take the opportunity to record my concern by speaking in this adjournment debate. The report was Audit Report No. 5, Efficiency Audit, Explosive Ordnance, Department of Defence.

PARA.TAB: One particular issue raised in this report has been a preoccupation of the Australian Democrats for some time. The Auditor-General sees a pressing need for a new east coast armaments complex, ECAC, to replace the Kingswood and Newington depots. The Democrats agree; however, the government has only said that it will move Newington. We would be very interested to hear from the minister on the future of Kingswood.

The government has dragged its feet on ECAC. Because the defence department and the minister have been fixated on building ECAC at Jervis Bay, they have repeatedly delayed taking a submission to cabinet, apparently in the vain hope that the opposition would just go away. Well, it has not and the government should bite the bullet and rule out Jervis Bay. There is no serious support for Jervis Bay in cabinet, yet the navy is still running a promotional campaign to drum up local support. This charade has to stop.

As the report notes, attention has been given to alternative sites for an ECAC, including Port Curtis near Gladstone, Point Wilson in Port Phillip Bay and Twofold Bay near Eden. The Auditor-General has found that the studies of alternative sites have been inadequate and that a new study with a broad based input is needed. That is a damning indictment of the department, with which the Democrats agree. The ECAC issue should be brought out of the closet and into the public domain. The secrecy has gone on for too long.

The auditor believes that plans for ECAC should be developed as part of a comprehensive explosive ordnance plan. The Democrats agree and would like to know why this has not happened before. We would add that the ECAC decision must be made as part of a naval facilities plan, especially given the well-sourced rumours that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is investigating the relocation of other naval facilities now in Sydney. Again, a piecemeal approach should be avoided. ECAC should be considered within a total facilities plan.

In our opinion, Gladstone has clear advantages as an ECAC site, particularly if the fleet base is moved there at a later date. Point Wilson has other virtues but comes equipped with one large obstacle: it is also the planned site of a chemical storage site to replace Coode Island in Melbourne's western suburbs and the two would not be compatible on present planning. We know that Defence has commissioned a Department of Administrative Services study on whether both facilities can be located at Point Wilson, separated by an appropriate safety zone. We have approached Senator Ray for a copy of the study and we would like him to expedite its release to cast some light on the ECAC debate.

It is high time the ECAC decision was finally made and made properly. The minister should concede that Jervis Bay is out of the question and that the public should be brought into the decision making process. This report underlines the fact that his department has failed to take an objective look at this issue. It is time someone else had a go.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise this evening a very serious matter and a very sorry matter. It shows the human cost of actions by people in the Public Service who do not appreciate that they are dealing with real people and real victims, in many cases, of grave injustices.

PARA.TAB: This story is about a woman called Mrs Nola Sillars. Mrs Nola Sillars cannot tell her story because on 10 September she took her life. She took her life in exasperation at what she saw as an uncooperative bureaucracy and a legal system in relation to corporations which was very difficult to understand. Having discussed the matter with her surviving partner, I thought it appropriate that we lay these matters before the Senate.

Mrs Sillars was married originally to a gentleman called Mr Ian Sillars and they lived in Western Australia. They jointly owned, through a company called Ticket Seal International Pty Ltd, the machinery and the rights to produce scratch-off lottery tickets and scratch-off promotional tickets that some honourable senators may have received in places such as McDonald's and so on.

Mr and Mrs Sillars had a marital separation in early 1983 and she sought some legal advice. In retrospect, I think the legal advice she received was poor, to say the least. It may also have been that the legal advice she received was not given in her best interests. She sought to have the assets of the company and the associated family assets frozen, for the creditors to be paid, and then to sort out the financial arrangements between herself and her husband. It seems as though she was advised that the appropriate way to do that was not to put the company into liquidation, a belief that she held for the remainder of her life. I believe that she may have been poorly advised in that and that, had a separate course of action been followed, maybe this problem would not have occurred.

It appears, however, that her solicitor was not diligent in pursuing Mrs Sillars's instructions. I also note that her solicitor later served a gaol sentence in Western Australia for matters arising from misconduct during the course of his professional duties, but not in relation to Mrs Sillars's case. Mrs Sillars, however, believed that he should have been gaoled for misconduct in relation to her case.

Subsequently, it appears that her husband took the assets of the company—the machinery, the rights, the contracts and everything—went to Sydney and continued to trade under the name, not of Ticket Seal International Pty Ltd, but Ticket Seal International Sydney. My office has conducted company searches with the Australian Securities Commission and although we can find Ticket Seal International Pty Ltd, which is now a company in liquidation, there seems no evidence that there was ever a Ticket Seal International Sydney.

What is even more disturbing is that, before the company in Western Australia was liquidated, Mr Sillars alienated all of the assets of the company for the princely sum of $5,000—what is known in the insolvency game as the sideways shuffle: all of the assets go one way and all of the liabilities stay where they are.

Mrs Sillars had extreme difficulty in trying to get an amicable solution to this. During the disputation her 12-year-old daughter was also kidnapped from her. I understand that she did not see her after that time. She sought, with no success, to have Mr Sillars brought to justice for the things that he had done. The fraud squad in Western Australia looked at it and seemed to have arrived at the conclusion that it was too difficult. It subsequently appeared that after much pressure from Mrs Sillars the liquidator of the company did form a view that Mr Sillars's conduct was legally unsatisfactory. But Mr Sillars cannot be brought to answer for that because he has fled to the United States and shows little intention of returning to this jurisdiction.

My concern was in relation to Mrs Sillars's attempts to get some explanation from the Australian Securities Commission as to what had happened. Her letters to the Australian Securities Commission are truly depressing. There is one letter on the file dated 11 November 1992 pointing out that in that year she had written to the Australian Securities Commission on 11 October, 16 October, 22 October and 26 October. She also wrote to the Australian Securities Commission on 15 December and again on 26 January this year. What she sought was some information in relation to the winding-up of the company. In particular, she sought to be assured that the information that she had provided at what she obviously thought could have been a grave risk to her own personal safety had been acted upon. The Australian Securities Commission was very unwilling to provide the information.

Ultimately, on 12 February 1993, a letter was received by Mrs Sillars. In fairness to the ASC, it is not a bad letter, but it could have gone further. It indicates that the liquidator of the company spent six years pursuing a preference action which was subsequently lost. I do not pass any judgment on that, but it does seem very strange that it would take six years to bring and pursue a preference action.

It also appears that the liquidator sought advice as to whether Mr Sillars could be pursued in relation to what was described as possible bankruptcy action and the outcome of a charging action relating to another company, but it appeared that there was no possibility of bringing him to justice. One wonders, however, why this conclusion was not arrived at until after Mr Sillars had had ample opportunity to strip the company bare and flee the jurisdiction. That should be a source of some concern. The Securities Commission refused to release the section 418 report which dealt with these matters in detail.

Mrs Sillars, being both a former director of and contributory to the company, was also a person against whom it may have been possible to raise imputations if one were not seeking to form an honest opinion of the facts. Having looked at the file, I do not believe there is any ground for believing that Mrs Sillars acted in anything other than the best interests of the creditors, her family and her good name.

She was so frustrated by this that she contacted me and other senators, seeking assistance, to get the relevant information released to her. On 10 September she gave up waiting and took her own life. On 15 September my staff received a letter from the Australian Securities Commission, which appears a little confused. It states that thus far the commission has not had to consider the question of whether or not a section 533 report or a section 418 report is available for access pursuant to the FOI act. One of the concerning things is that Mrs Sillars did not have the resources to pay the costs associated with an FOI application.

When people have given information to assist organisations such as the Australian Securities Commission or people who are charged with responsibility under the corporations law, perhaps consideration ought to be given to waiving those charges. I think it is also necessary for us to consider whether it is possible to release to people information contained in some reports which at least shows them that their cooperative action has been worth while. It may be that some sort of briefing information can be provided under privilege. It may be that edited forms of the documents can be provided.

None of this makes much difference now, I suppose, to Mrs Sillars. The wishes of her family are that this matter be pursued and that we attempt to get a change in attitude so that dreadful situations like this do not happen again. I cannot help reflecting on the conversation I had with her partner. She was fortunate enough in the last years of her life to have a loving and caring partner in Sydney. His stated wish to her on many occasions was that maybe she should give up this fight. He wanted her to settle down and for them to get married. I have spoken with him. He is a very good man and a man who is immensely upset by what has occurred. I wish to place on the record here, in this place, at this time, my condolences to him, to Mrs Sillars's surviving family and to the people who attempted to support her.

I hope that those who could have been more cooperative in the discharge of their public duties will recognise that real people bear the costs of their inaction and that they have an obligation to everybody to discharge their duty properly. I hope that this may be a salutary lesson and that we will never again have to go through this dreadful situation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I would like to inform the Senate of the successful completion of the recent mission overseas to commemorate the 75th anniversary of the battles on the Western Front. Fourteen World War I veterans, seven war widows and two junior legatees joined me, Senator MacGibbon and many others on a mission which left for France on Friday, 27 August, and returned on the morning of Monday, 6 September. The opposition was ably represented by Senator MacGibbon. The honourable member for Bennelong, Mr John Howard, from the House of Representatives, also participated in the mission. Although it was in a personal capacity, it was certainly to a very significant extent.

PARA.TAB: The group included Mr August Band, Mr Edward Field, Mr Edward Smout and Mrs Myrtle Shand from Queensland; Mr Bruce Heathcote, Mr Howard Pope, Mr Hugh O'Donnell and Mrs Gwen Serviss from South Australia; Mr Stanley Graham, Mr William Davies, Mr Alexander Griffiths and Mrs Pat Graham from New South Wales; Mr Harry Poulton and Mrs Margaret Burns from Victoria; Mr Robert Comb and Mrs Erica Weller from the ACT; Mr Robert Lewis, Mr Alfred Evans and Mrs Florence Carr from Tasmania; and we were accompanied by Mr Peter Casserly and Mrs Zoe Hall from Western Australia.

The junior legatees accompanying the mission were Elizabeth Livingstone, age 17, of Queensland and Daniel Stein, aged 16, of Western Australia. As a tribute to the distinguished Commander of the Australian Army Corps in 1918, Lieutenant-General Sir John Monash, Monash University sponsored officer cadet Erin Palmer, a student and member of the university regiment. The Australian people were represented at the major commemorative ceremonies by the Governor-General, Bill Hayden, and Mrs Hayden.

The mission was supported in its tributes by a ceremonial guard and band drawn from the land command of the Australian Defence Force. Many of them were selected because they have family or regimental connections to the Western Front. The mission left on a high note with a farewell by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) from Lady Davidson Hospital followed by a gathering of well wishers and a civic farewell at the Sydney Town Hall. I believe that really set the scene for the entire visit.

As I understand the extensive media coverage of the mission conveyed, it was a most moving and enlightening experience for all those involved and certainly did pay appropriate tribute to the 46,000 Australians who died on the Western Front. For the diggers, who had of course experienced the horrors of war there, and the war widows, whose husbands fought there, it was a very emotional experience indeed. I think all members of the mission found the experience extraordinarily moving and certainly one that they will never forget. I think it is properly and genuinely described as the experience of a lifetime for all involved.

The itinerary for the week of the mission included commemorative events at all the significant battlefields where Australians fought and coincided with the 75th anniversary of the great Australian victories at Mont St Quentin and Peronne. The mission began with a mass at Les Invalides on the morning of Sunday 29 August, followed by a commemoration service at the Arc de Triomphe and a reception at the Australian Embassy attended by the Governor-General and Mrs Hayden.

The next day the mission travelled to Villers-Bretonneux for the first major commemoration ceremony at the Australian memorial and in the presence of the Governor-General. This was followed by wreath laying ceremonies at the 3rd Division memorial at Sally-le-Sec and the 1st Australian Division memorial at Pozieres. A civic reception was held that night in the magnificent Arras Town Hall.

On Wednesday, 1 September the mission travelled to Fromelles for a wreath laying ceremony at the VC Corner cemetery and then on to Ypres to visit the battlefield sites and lay wreaths at the 5th Division memorial at Polygon Wood. After a civic reception at the Cloth Hall in Ypres, the ADF contingent marched through the town to the Menin Gate memorial which now, of course, is very much a peaceful landscape and very different from that experienced by the predecessors of that ADF contingent during the First World War. That evening a major commemoration ceremony was held at the Menin Gate.

On Thursday, members of the mission visited the Australian Memorial at Bullecourt and on Friday, 3 September we travelled to Mont St Quentin where wreaths were laid at the 2nd Division memorial. Meanwhile, the ADF guard and band assembled at the Peronne Town Hall, marched from there to L'Historiale where the 75th anniversary of the liberation of Peronne by Australian forces on 3 September 1918 was commemorated. A wreath was also laid at the 4th Division memorial at Bellenglise before the mission returned to Paris and from there back to Australia the next day.

I would like to mention that a souvenir issue of the mission's itinerary, which sets out in some detail the return to the Western Front mission, is being produced jointly by the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Defence Force Journal.

At the major battlefields we visited a total of 11 large plaques sculpted by Dr Ross Bastiaan were unveiled. The plaques inform visitors of the activities of Australian soldiers in the local area during World War I. I think they are a splendid and certainly innovative addition to our historical record. I join others in sincerely thanking Dr Bastiaan and his sponsors for the fine work and community spirit that they have shown in producing these plaques.

As part of the ceremonies at the battlefields, the Last Post was sounded on the bugle used by Corporal Claude Potter to rally the 8th Battalion into action on the Somme. It was lent by his son Mr Graham Potter of Western Australia and I would like to thank him for his generous gesture. At each ceremony the scene was set by the delivery of a prologue by the Deputy Director of the Australian War Memorial, Dr Michael McKernan. These prologues vividly described the actions of Australians who fought in the area in World War I and the significance of each of the sites we visited to Australia's military history. The prologues set the scene for the ceremonies and certainly, I believe, brought into focus the purpose of the commemorations.

The Governor-General hosted a reception in each of the communities associated with the major commemoration ceremonies and also at Fromelles and Bullecourt. These provided opportunities for our veterans and war widows to meet the local people who turned out in very large numbers. I think all of us were very pleased to see a great number of local children paying tribute to the diggers on their return to France and Belgium.

I would like to place on the record my thanks to the French government for its generous assistance and logistic support for the ADF ceremonial contingent. In all the areas that we visited, the French community warmly welcomed the mission and joined in the commemorative activities, as did the local communities in Belgium, and they certainly recalled the days in 1916 to 1918 when close links between our nations were established.

I would also like to commend the Australian Defence Force for the absolutely magnificent way in which it performed its important ceremonial support role during the mission. In my judgment, its participation helped to make the national tribute to those who sacrificed their lives on the Western Front a full and appropriate one.

To the World War I veterans and the war widows who took part in the mission, I can only join Senator MacGibbon in expressing my highest admiration for their remarkable courage and stamina during the mission. I think it is fair to say that they were an inspiration to all of us on that mission and, I have heard since my return, certainly an inspiration to all at home.

I believe that everyone who accompanied the mission was really grateful for the opportunity to see at first hand where these veterans had fought, and really appreciated the opportunity to share with them the moving tributes to their fallen comrades. As I said, it was an experience that will never be repeated for any of us.

Sadly, Mr Hugh O'Donnell, who was a veteran from South Australia, died a week after returning from the mission. I am pleased to say that, even though he developed health problems on the trip, he really was determined to participate fully in our mission—and, indeed, he did just that. On his return to Australia, his health gave rise to some concern and he was admitted to Concord Repatriation General Hospital in Sydney for observation. The Department of Veterans' Affairs flew his wife and daughter to be with him during his last few days and, as I say, he died soon afterwards. It really was a privilege to know such a fine old man, and I certainly express my deepest sympathy to his wife and family.

I would like also to report to the Senate and to the Australian people that our war dead of the Western Front rest certainly in peaceful circumstances, obviously a peace for which they unselfishly gave their lives. It was a great opportunity for us in France and Belgium to see the role that the Commonwealth War Graves Commission plays. I believe that all who were on the mission were genuinely impressed with the way memorials and cemeteries have been kept throughout the Western Front.

I would like also to place on record my gratitude to all those who were involved in organising and conducting such a successful mission. It was planned and it was executed in an absolutely exemplary manner by the Department of Veterans' Affairs. The veterans and war widows, who were the focus of the mission, received the very best of care throughout the mission.

In particular, I would like to thank the medical team and the carers who attended to the veterans group with real skill, real commitment and real compassion. I would like to offer the staff of the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the Department of Defence my thanks, my appreciation and my congratulations for a job very well done. I believe that it is an achievement they can be justly proud of.

The 75th anniversary commemorations of World War I will culminate on 11 November, Armistice Day, with the dedication of the tomb of the unknown soldier at the Australian War Memorial. This will be the last significant anniversary of the First World War at which surviving Australians from that conflict can be present and in which they can participate. The tomb will provide a solemn and inspirational focal point for the large number of Australians and others who visit the memorial each year. With overseas battlefields, cemeteries and memorials so far away, I think the tomb is going to be a place where visitors can go to grieve, to place a flower of tribute or remembrance, to remember, and to reflect—and to do that in this country, Australia.

When I announced on 7 July the names of the veterans and war widows who would be taking part in the 75th anniversary commemorative mission to the Western Front, I observed that there would obviously be very great disappointment amongst those who were selected for the reserve group for the mission but who would not be part of the mission. I invited them at that time to travel to Canberra with a family member or carer, at government expense, to attend the dedication of the tomb of the unknown soldier. I certainly hope they will be able to join us here—I believe they will—and I think that this event will be a very fitting climax to the government's very full and significant program of commemorative events to remember and honour Australia's participation in World War I.

Finally, again I would say a sincere thankyou to the veterans, the war widows and all those who accompanied this commemorative mission to the Western Front. I believe that our veterans and war widows really did our country proud in France and Belgium, as did the veterans, of course, before in 1916 to 1918. I know that the whole of the delegation—everyone on the mission—was honoured, as I certainly was, to be part of this historic occasion. It is an experience that I will certainly never forget. I am sure that for all those who participated in the mission it is something which will stand as perhaps one of the most important life experiences and certainly something that will stay with us for the remainder of our lives.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.TAB: The number of Commonwealth Government employees on the Department of Finance PAY system who were issued with a group certificate on the Department's Tasmanian Tax Employer Group are shown at Attachment A.

For the 1990-91, 1991-92 and 1992-93 financial years, the number of group certificates issued was obtained from the Department of Finance PAY system, Reconciliation of Group Certificates Issued Report for the Tasmanian Employer Group. Those reports have a statutory retention period of seven

ANSWER.PARA: years only. The number of group certificates issued for the 1983-84 financial year was obtained from another PAY system report; the Form 25 History.

PARA.TAB: It should be noted that the number of group certificates issued does not accurately reflect the number of Commonwealth Government employees actually located in Tasmania as at the 30 June in each or any year for the following reasons:
it includes group certificates issued on retirement, resignation and death;
where an employee is promoted, or transfers, to another agency in that state it includes issues on behalf of both the losing and gaining agencies;
it includes employees with different periods of employment, eg casual employees;

where the personnel functions of some agencies are either centralised in Canberra or carried out in another state, eg Victoria, the group certificate issue records for employees located in Tasmania are reflected against the payroll of the servicing state, ie not against Tasmania; and

some Government Business Enterprises (or sections thereof) have not been a user of the Department of Finance PAY sytem while other agencies, such as the Civil Aviation Authority, have chosen to leave that system.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 25 August 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the 1993-94 Budget measures concerning unused annual leave and long service leave lump sum payments:
(1) How will this measure affect members of the Australian Defence Force.
(2) Are both the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits and Military Superannuation Schemes `approved early retirement schemes'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) For the Australian Defence Force, unused long service leave lump sum payments accrued up to 17 August 1993 will continue to attract a concessional rate of tax. Future long service leave lump sum entitlements as well as all unused annual leave will be taxed as normal income. As announced in the Budget, existing concessions will remain for bona fide redundancies, invalidities and approved early retirement schemes. This is identical to the way the Budget measures apply to the rest of the community.

(2) No. The Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Scheme and the Military Superannuation and Benefits Scheme are not early retirement schemes. They are Funds providing superannuation, invalidity and death benefits and are not to be confused with early retirement schemes which provide for the early termination for employment of employees. The Budget measures have no effect on the two military superannuation schemes.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 31 August 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) How much notice is given to employees by COMCARE of decisions to cease payments of benefits.
(2) How many days notice of decisions to terminate payment of benefits is given to employees by the Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation (AOTC) and Australia Post in each State.
(3) Was a mere 9 days notice of a decision to terminate benefits given to a long-term injured employee of AOTC in Western Australia in December 1992.

(4) Have complaints about the short notice being given by AOTC in Western Australia been received by COMCARE; if so, what actions have been taken to ensure that AOTC more closely follows COMCARE's procedures in relation to termination of benefits.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Comcare Australia generally allows all employees 28 days to present their case where an entitlement is under review. Depending on the circumstances of each case, an extension of time may be given. For current employees, the appropriate date for the actual cessation of the payment of benefit is agreed between Comcare Australia and the employing agency. Payments to former employees who are paid directly by Comcare Australia are ceased from the commencement of the next available pay period.

(2) The national policy of Telstra (formerly AOTC) allows employees a minimum of 14 days in which to respond to advice of an intention to cease entitlement, or to seek further time to provide fresh evidence. In all other regards, its practice is the same as that of Comcare Australia. Australia Post's national practice is the same as that of Comcare Australia.
(3) Telstra is not able to identify this particular claim.

(4) No. However, an inconsistency of practice with regard to the ceasing of entitlement was identified during an evaluation undertaken by the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Commission. The evaluation specifically focused on the consistency of practices and procedures followed by Comcare Australia, Telstra and Australia Post. As a result of the evaluation Telstra issued its national policy regarding advice of intention to cease entitlement.
